Now, how shall we glorify, how shall we exalt, God in our body, which is doomed to perish? We must now encounter the subject of marriage, which Marcion, more continent than the apostle, prohibits.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:28
verses.text: For the apostle, although preferring the grace of continence, yet permits the contraction of marriage and the enjoyment of it, and advises the continuance therein rather than the dissolution thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:29
verses.text: Christ plainly forbids divorce, Moses unquestionably permits it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:30
verses.text: Now, when Marcion wholly prohibits all carnal intercourse to the faithful (for we will say nothing about his catechumens), and when he prescribes repudiation of all engagements before marriage, whose teaching does he follow, that of Moses or of Christ? Even Christ, however, when He here commands "the wife not to depart from her husband, or if she depart, to remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband," both permitted divorce, which indeed He never absolutely prohibited, and confirmed (the sanctity) of marriage, by first forbidding its dissolution; and, if separation had taken place, by wishing the nuptial bond to be resumed by reconciliation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:31
verses.text: But what reasons does (the apostle) allege for continence?  Because "the time is short".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:32
verses.text: I had almost thought it was because in Christ there was another god! And yet He from whom emanates this shortness of the time, will also send what suits the said brevity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:33
verses.text: No one makes provision for the time which is another's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:34
verses.text: You degrade your god, O Marcion, when you make him circumscribed at all by the Creator's time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:35
verses.text: Assuredly also, when (the apostle) rules that marriage should be "only in the Lord," that no Christian should intermarry with a heathen, he maintains a law of the Creator, who everywhere prohibits marriage with strangers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:36
verses.text: But when he says, "although there be that are called gods, whether in heaven or in earth," the meaning of his words is clear—not as if there were gods in reality, but as if there were some who are called gods, without being truly so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:37
verses.text: He introduces his discussion about meats offered to idols with a statement concerning idols (themselves): "We know that an idol is nothing in the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:38
verses.text: Marcion, however, does not say that the Creator is not God; so that the apostle can hardly be thought to have ranked the Creator amongst those who are called gods, without being so; since, even if they had been gods, "to us there is but one God, the Father".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:39
verses.text: Now, from whom do all things come to us, but from Him to whom all things belong? And pray, what things are these? You have them in a preceding part of the epistle:  "All things are yours; whether Paul, or Apollos, or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:40
verses.text: He makes the Creator, then the God of all things, from whom proceed both the world and life and death, which cannot possibly belong to the other god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:41
verses.text: From Him, therefore, amongst the "all things" comes also Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:42
verses.text: When he teaches that every man ought to live of his own industry, he begins with a copious induction of examples—of soldiers, and shepherds, and husbandmen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:43
verses.text: But he wanted divine authority.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:44
verses.text: What was the use, however, of adducing the Creator's, which he was destroying? It was vain to do so; for his god had no such authority! (The apostle) says: "Thou shalt not muzzle the ox that treadeth out the corn," and adds: "Doth God take care of oxen?" Yes, of oxen, for the sake of men! For, says he, "it is written for our sakes".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:45
verses.text: Thus he showed that the law had a symbolic reference to ourselves, and that it gives its sanction in favour of those who live of the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:46
verses.text: (He showed) also, that those who preach the gospel are on this account sent by no other god but Him to whom belongs the law, which made provision for them, when he says: "For our sakes was this written".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:47
verses.text: Still he declined to use this power which the law gave him, because he preferred working without any restraint.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:48
verses.text: Of this he boasted, and suffered no man to rob him of such glory—certainly with no view of destroying the law, which he proved that another man might use.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:49
verses.text: For behold Marcion, in his blindness, stumbled at the rock whereof our fathers drank in the wilderness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:50
verses.text: For since "that rock was Christ," it was, of course, the Creator's, to whom also belonged the people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:51
verses.text: But why resort to the figure of a sacred sign given by an extraneous god? Was it to teach the very truth, that ancient things prefigured the Christ who was to be educed out of them? For, being about to take a cursory view of what befell the people (of Israel) he begins with saying: "Now these things happened as examples for us".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:52
verses.text: Now, tell me, were these examples given by the Creator to men belonging to a rival god?  Or did one god borrow examples from another, and a hostile one too? He withdraws me to himself in alarm from Him from whom he transfers my allegiance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:53
verses.text: Will his antagonist make me better disposed to him? Should I now commit the same sins as the people, shall I have to suffer the same penalties, or not? But if not the same, how vainly does he propose to me terrors which I shall not have to endure! From whom, again, shall I have to endure them? If from the Creator, What evils does it appertain to Him to inflict? And how will it happen that, jealous God as He is, He shall punish the man who offends His rival, instead of rather encouraging him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:54
verses.text: If, however, from the other god—but he knows not how to punish.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:55
verses.text: So that the whole declaration of the apostle lacks a reasonable basis, if it is not meant to relate to the Creator's discipline.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:56
verses.text: But the fact is, the apostle's conclusion corresponds to the beginning:  "Now all these things happened unto them for ensamples; and they are written for our admonition, upon whom the ends of the world are come".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:57
verses.text: What a Creator! how prescient already, and considerate in warning Christians who belong to another god! Whenever cavils occur the like to those which have been already dealt with, I pass them by; certain others I despatch briefly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:58
verses.text: A great argument for another god is the permission to eat of all kinds of meats, contrary to the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:59
verses.text: Just as if we did not ourselves allow that the burdensome ordinances of the law were abrogated—but by Him who imposed them, who also promised the new condition of things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:60
verses.text: The same, therefore, who prohibited meats, also restored the use of them, just as He had indeed allowed them from the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 7:61
verses.text: If, however, some strange god had come to destroy our God, his foremost prohibition would certainly have been, that his own votaries should abstain from supporting their lives on the resources of his adversary.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:1
verses.text: Man the Image of the Creator, and Christ the Head of the Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:2
verses.text: Spiritual Gifts.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:3
verses.text: The Sevenfold Spirit Described by Isaiah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:4
verses.text: The Apostle and the Prophet Compared.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:5
verses.text: Marcion Challenged to Produce Anything Like These Gifts of the Spirit Foretold in Prophecy in His God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:6
verses.text: "The head of every man is Christ".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:7
verses.text: What Christ, if He is not the author of man? The head he has here put for authority; now "authority" will accrue to none else than the "author".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:8
verses.text: Of what man indeed is He the head? Surely of him concerning whom he adds soon afterwards: "The man ought not to cover his head, forasmuch as he is the image of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:9
verses.text: Since then he is the image of the Creator (for He, when looking on Christ His Word, who was to become man, said, "Let us make man in our own image, after our likeness"), how can I possibly have another head but Him whose image I am? For if I am the image of the Creator there is no room in me for another head.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:10
verses.text: But wherefore "ought the woman to have power over her head, because of the angels?" If it is because "she was created for the man," and taken out of the man, according to the Creator's purpose, then in this way too has the apostle maintained the discipline of that God from whose institution he explains the reasons of His discipline.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:11
verses.text: He adds:  "Because of the angels".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:12
verses.text: What angels?  In other words, whose angels? If he means the fallen angels of the Creator, there is great propriety in his meaning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:13
verses.text: It is right that that face which was a snare to them should wear some mark of a humble guise and obscured beauty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:14
verses.text: If, however, the angels of the rival god are referred to, what fear is there for them? for not even Marcion's disciples, (to say nothing of his angels,) have any desire for women.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:15
verses.text: We have often shown before now, that the apostle classes heresies as evil among "works of the flesh," and that he would have those persons accounted estimable who shun heresies as an evil thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:16
verses.text: In like manner, when treating of the gospel, we have proved from the sacrament of the bread and the cup the verity of the Lord's body and blood in opposition to Marcion's phantom; whilst throughout almost the whole of my work it has been contended that all mention of judicial attributes points conclusively to the Creator as to a God who judges.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:17
verses.text: Now, on the subject of "spiritual gifts," I have to remark that these also were promised by the Creator through Christ; and I think that we may derive from this a very just conclusion that the bestowal of a gift is not the work of a god other than Him who is proved to have given the promise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:18
verses.text: Here is a prophecy of Isaiah: "There shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a flower shall spring up from his root; and upon Him shall rest the Spirit of the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:19
verses.text: After which he enumerates the special gifts of the same: "The spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of religion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:20
verses.text: And with the fear of the Lord shall the Spirit fill Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:21
verses.text: In this figure of a flower he shows that Christ was to arise out of the rod which sprang from the stem of Jesse; in other words, from the virgin of the race of David, the son of Jesse.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:22
verses.text: In this Christ the whole substantia of the Spirit would have to rest, not meaning that it would be as it were some subsequent acquisition accruing to Him who was always, even before His incarnation, the Spirit of God; so that you cannot argue from this that the prophecy has reference to that Christ who (as mere man of the race only of David) was to obtain the Spirit of his God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:23
verses.text: (The prophet says,) on the contrary, that from the time when (the true Christ) should appear in the flesh as the flower predicted, rising from the root of Jesse, there would have to rest upon Him the entire operation of the Spirit of grace, which, so far as the Jews were concerned, would cease and come to an end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:24
verses.text: This result the case itself shows; for after this time the Spirit of the Creator never breathed amongst them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:25
verses.text: From Judah were taken away "the wise man, and the cunning artificer, and the counsellor, and the prophet;" that so it might prove true that "the law and the prophets were until John".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:26
verses.text: Now hear how he declared that by Christ Himself, when returned to heaven, these spiritual gifts were to be sent: "He ascended up on high," that is, into heaven; "He led captivity captive," meaning death or slavery of man; "He gave gifts to the sons of men," that is, the gratuities, which we call charismata.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:27
verses.text: He says specifically "sons of men," and not men promiscuously; thus exhibiting to us those who were the children of men truly so called, choice men, apostles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:28
verses.text: "For," says he, "I have begotten you through the gospel;" and "Ye are my children, of whom I travail again in birth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:29
verses.text: Now was absolutely fulfilled that promise of the Spirit which was given by the word of Joel:  "In the last days will I pour out of my Spirit upon all flesh, and their sons and their daughters shall prophesy; and upon my servants and upon my handmaids will I pour out of my Spirit".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:30
verses.text: Since, then, the Creator promised the gift of His Spirit in the latter days; and since Christ has in these last days appeared as the dispenser of spiritual gifts (as the apostle says, "When the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth His Son;" and again, "This I say, brethren, that the time is short"), it evidently follows in connection with this prediction of the last days, that this gift of the Spirit belongs to Him who is the Christ of the predicters.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:31
verses.text: Now compare the Spirit's specific graces, as they are described by the apostle, and promised by the prophet Isaiah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:32
verses.text: "To one is given," says he, "by the Spirit the word of wisdom;" this we see at once is what Isaiah declared to be "the spirit of wisdom".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:33
verses.text: "To another, the word of knowledge;" this will be "the (prophet's) spirit of understanding and counsel".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:34
verses.text: "To another, faith by the same Spirit;" this will be "the spirit of religion and the fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:35
verses.text: "To another, the gifts of healing, and to another the working of miracles;" this will be "the spirit of might".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:36
verses.text: "To another prophecy, to another discerning of spirits, to another divers kinds of tongues, to another the interpretation of tongues;" this will be "the spirit of knowledge".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:37
verses.text: See how the apostle agrees with the prophet both in making the distribution of the one Spirit, and in interpreting His special graces.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:38
verses.text: This, too, I may confidently say: he who has likened the unity of our body throughout its manifold and divers members to the compacting together of the various gifts of the Spirit, shows also that there is but one Lord of the human body and of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:39
verses.text: This Spirit, (according to the apostle's showing,) meant not that the service of these gifts should be in the body, nor did He place them in the human body); and on the subject of the superiority of love above all these gifts, He even taught the apostle that it was the chief commandment, just as Christ has shown it to be: "Thou shalt love the Lord with all thine heart and soul, with all thy strength, and with all thy mind, and thy neighbour as thine own self".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:40
verses.text: When he mentions the fact that "it is written in the law," how that the Creator would speak with other tongues and other lips, whilst confirming indeed the gift of tongues by such a mention, he yet cannot be thought to have affirmed that the gift was that of another god by his reference to the Creator's prediction.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:41
verses.text: In precisely the same manner, when enjoining on women silence in the church, that they speak not for the mere sake of learning (although that even they have the right of prophesying, he has already shown when he covers the woman that prophesies with a veil), he goes to the law for his sanction that woman should be under obedience.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:42
verses.text: Now this law, let me say once for all, he ought to have made no other acquaintance with, than to destroy it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:43
verses.text: But that we may now leave the subject of spiritual gifts, facts themselves will be enough to prove which of us acts rashly in claiming them for his God, and whether it is possible that they are opposed to our side, even if the Creator promised them for His Christ who is not yet revealed, as being destined only for the Jews, to have their operations in His time, in His Christ, and among His people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:44
verses.text: Let Marcion then exhibit, as gifts of his god, some prophets, such as have not spoken by human sense, but with the Spirit of God, such as have both predicted things to come, and have made manifest the secrets of the heart; let him produce a psalm, a vision, a prayer—only let it be by the Spirit, in an ecstasy, that is, in a rapture, whenever an interpretation of tongues has occurred to him; let him show to me also, that any woman of boastful tongue in his community has ever prophesied from amongst those specially holy sisters of his.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:45
verses.text: Now all these signs (of spiritual gifts) are forthcoming from my side without any difficulty, and they agree, too, with the rules, and the dispensations, and the instructions of the Creator; therefore without doubt the Christ, and the Spirit, and the apostle, belong severally to my God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 8:46
verses.text: Here, then, is my frank avowal for any one who cares to require it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:1
verses.text: The Doctrine of the Resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:2
verses.text: The Body Will Rise Again.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:3
verses.text: Christ's Judicial Character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:4
verses.text: Jewish Perversions of Prophecy Exposed and Confuted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:5
verses.text: Messianic Psalms Vindicated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:6
verses.text: Jewish and Rationalistic Interpretations on This Point Similar.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:7
verses.text: Jesus—Not Hezekiah or Solomon—The Subject of These Prophecies in the Psalms.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:8
verses.text: None But He is the Christ of the Old and the New Testaments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:9
verses.text: Meanwhile the Marcionite will exhibit nothing of this kind; he is by this time afraid to say which side has the better right to a Christ who is not yet revealed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:10
verses.text: Just as my Christ is to be expected, who was predicted from the beginning, so his Christ therefore has no existence, as not having been announced from the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:11
verses.text: Ours is a better faith, which believes in a future Christ, than the heretic's, which has none at all to believe in.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:12
verses.text: Touching the resurrection of the dead, let us first inquire how some persons then denied it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:13
verses.text: No doubt in the same way in which it is even now denied, since the resurrection of the flesh has at all times men to deny it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:14
verses.text: But many wise men claim for the soul a divine nature, and are confident of its undying destiny, and even the multitude worship the dead in the presumption which they boldly entertain that their souls survive.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:15
verses.text: As for our bodies, however, it is manifest that they perish either at once by fire or the wild beasts, or even when most carefully kept by length of time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:16
verses.text: When, therefore, the apostle refutes those who deny the resurrection of the flesh, he indeed defends, in opposition to them, the precise matter of their denial, that is, the resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:17
verses.text: You have the whole answer wrapped up in this.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:18
verses.text: All the rest is superfluous.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:19
verses.text: Now in this very point, which is called the resurrection of the dead, it is requisite that the proper force of the words should be accurately maintained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:20
verses.text: The word dead expresses simply what has lost the vital principle, by means of which it used to live.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:21
verses.text: Now the body is that which loses life, and as the result of losing it becomes dead.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:22
verses.text: To the body, therefore, the term dead is only suitable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:23
verses.text: Moreover, as resurrection accrues to what is dead, and dead is a term applicable only to a body, therefore the body alone has a resurrection incidental to it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:24
verses.text: So again the word Resurrection, or (rising again), embraces only that which has fallen down.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:25
verses.text: "To rise," indeed, can be predicated of that which has never fallen down, but had already been always lying down.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:26
verses.text: But "to rise again" is predicable only of that which has fallen down; because it is by rising again, in consequence of its having fallen down, that it is said to have re-risen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:27
verses.text: For the syllable RE always implies iteration (or happening again).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:28
verses.text: We say, therefore, that the body falls to the ground by death, as indeed facts themselves show, in accordance with the law of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:29
verses.text: For to the body it was said, ("Till thou return to the ground, for out of it wast thou taken; for) dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:30
verses.text: That, therefore, which came from the ground shall return to the ground.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:31
verses.text: Now that falls down which returns to the ground; and that rises again which falls down.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:32
verses.text: "Since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:33
verses.text: Here in the word man, who consists of bodily substance, as we have often shown already, is presented to me the body of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:34
verses.text: But if we are all so made alive in Christ, as we die in Adam, it follows of necessity that we are made alive in Christ as a bodily substance, since we died in Adam as a bodily substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:35
verses.text: The similarity, indeed, is not complete, unless our revival in Christ concur in identity of substance with our mortality in Adam.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:36
verses.text: But at this point (the apostle) has made a parenthetical statement concerning Christ, which, bearing as it does on our present discussion, must not pass unnoticed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:37
verses.text: For the resurrection of the body will receive all the better proof, in proportion as I shall succeed in showing that Christ belongs to that God who is believed to have provided this resurrection of the flesh in His dispensation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:38
verses.text: When he says, "For He must reign, till He hath put all enemies under His feet," we can see at once from this statement that he speaks of a God of vengeance, and therefore of Him who made the following promise to Christ:  "Sit Thou at my right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:39
verses.text: The rod of Thy strength shall the Lord send forth from Sion, and He shall rule along with Thee in the midst of Thine enemies".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:40
verses.text: It is necessary for me to lay claim to those Scriptures which the Jews endeavour to deprive us of, and to show that they sustain my view.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:41
verses.text: Now they say that this Psalm was a chant in honour of Hezekiah, because "he went up to the house of the Lord," and God turned back and removed his enemies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:42
verses.text: Therefore, (as they further hold,) those other words, "Before the morning star did I beget thee from the womb," are applicable to Hezekiah, and to the birth of Hezekiah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:43
verses.text: We on our side have published Gospels (to the credibility of which we have to thank them for having given some confirmation, indeed, already in so great a subject); and these declare that the Lord was born at night, that so it might be "before the morning star," as is evident both from the star especially, and from the testimony of the angel, who at night announced to the shepherds that Christ had at that moment been born, and again from the place of the birth, for it is towards night that persons arrive at the (eastern) "inn".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:44
verses.text: Perhaps, too, there was a mystic purpose in Christ's being born at night, destined, as He was, to be the light of the truth amidst the dark shadows of ignorance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:45
verses.text: Nor, again, would God have said, "I have begotten Thee," except to His true Son.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:46
verses.text: For although He says of all the people (Israel), "I have begotten children," yet He added not "from the womb".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:47
verses.text: Now, why should He have added so superfluously this phrase "from the womb" (as if there could be any doubt about any one's having been born from the womb), unless the Holy Ghost had wished the words to be with especial care understood of Christ? "I have begotten Thee from the womb," that is to say, from a womb only, without a man's seed, making it a condition of a fleshly body that it should come out of a womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:48
verses.text: What is here added (in the Psalm), "Thou art a priest for ever," relates to (Christ) Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:49
verses.text: Hezekiah was no priest; and even if he had been one, he would not have been a priest for ever.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:50
verses.text: "After the order," says He, "of Melchizedek".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:51
verses.text: Now what had Hezekiah to do with Melchizedek, the priest of the most high God, and him uncircumcised too, who blessed the circumcised Abraham, after receiving from him the offering of tithes? To Christ, however, "the order of Melchizedek" will be very suitable; for Christ is the proper and legitimate High Priest of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:52
verses.text: He is the Pontiff of the priesthood of the uncircumcision, constituted such, even then, for the Gentiles, by whom He was to be more fully received, although at His last coming He will favour with His acceptance and blessing the circumcision also, even the race of Abraham, which by and by is to acknowledge Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:53
verses.text: Well, then, there is also another Psalm, which begins with these words: "Give Thy judgments, O God, to the King," that is, to Christ who was to come as King, "and Thy righteousness unto the King's son," that is, to Christ's people; for His sons are they who are born again in Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:54
verses.text: But it will here be said that this Psalm has reference to Solomon.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:55
verses.text: However, will not those portions of the Psalm which apply to Christ alone, be enough to teach us that all the rest, too, relates to Christ, and not to Solomon? "He shall come down," says He, "like rain upon a fleece, and like dropping showers upon the earth," describing His descent from heaven to the flesh as gentle and unobserved.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:56
verses.text: Solomon, however, if he had indeed any descent at all, came not down like a shower, because he descended not from heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:57
verses.text: But I will set before you more literal points.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:58
verses.text: "He shall have dominion," says the Psalmist, "from sea to sea, and from the river unto the ends of the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:59
verses.text: To Christ alone was this given; whilst Solomon reigned over only the moderately-sized kingdom of Judah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:60
verses.text: "Yea, all kings shall fall down before Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:61
verses.text: Whom, indeed, shall they all thus worship, except Christ? "All nations shall serve Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:62
verses.text: To whom shall all thus do homage, but Christ? "His name shall endure for ever".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:63
verses.text: Whose name has this eternity of fame, but Christ's? "Longer than the sun shall His name remain," for longer than the sun shall be the Word of God, even Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:64
verses.text: "And in Him shall all nations be blessed".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:65
verses.text: In Solomon was no nation blessed; in Christ every nation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:66
verses.text: And what if the Psalm proves Him to be even God? "They shall call Him blessed".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:67
verses.text: (On what ground?) Because blessed is the Lord God of Israel, who only doeth wonderful things".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:68
verses.text: "Blessed also is His glorious name, and with His glory shall all the earth be filled".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:69
verses.text: On the contrary, Solomon (as I make bold to affirm) lost even the glory which he had from God, seduced by his love of women even into idolatry.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 9:70
verses.text: And thus, the statement which occurs in about the middle of this Psalm, "His enemies shall lick the dust" (of course, as having been, (to use the apostle's phrase,) "put under His feet"), will bear upon the very object which I had in view, when I both introduced the Psalm, and insisted on my opinion of its sense,—namely, that I might demonstrate both the glory of His kingdom and the subjection of His enemies in pursuance of the Creator's own plans, with the view of laying down this conclusion, that none but He can be believed to be the Christ of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:1
verses.text: Doctrine of the Resurrection of the Body, Continued.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:2
verses.text: How are the Dead Raised? and with What Body Do They Come? These Questions Answered in Such a Sense as to Maintain the Truth of the Raised Body, Against Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:3
verses.text: Christ as the Second Adam Connected with the Creator of the First Man.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:4
verses.text: Let Us Bear the Image of the Heavenly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:5
verses.text: The Triumph Over Death in Accordance with the Prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:6
verses.text: Hosea and St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:7
verses.text: Paul Compared.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:8
verses.text: Let us now return to the resurrection, to the defence of which against heretics of all sorts we have given indeed sufficient attention in another work of ours.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:9
verses.text: But we will not be wanting (in some defence of the doctrine) even here, in consideration of such persons as are ignorant of that little treatise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:10
verses.text: "What," asks he, "shall they do who are baptized for the dead, if the dead rise not?" Now, never mind that practice, (whatever it may have been.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:11
verses.text: )  The Februarian lustrations will perhaps answer him (quite as well), by praying for the dead.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:12
verses.text: Do not then suppose that the apostle here indicates some new god as the author and advocate of this (baptism for the dead.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:13
verses.text: His only aim in alluding to it was) that he might all the more firmly insist upon the resurrection of the body, in proportion as they who were vainly baptized for the dead resorted to the practice from their belief of such a resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:14
verses.text: We have the apostle in another passage defining "but one baptism".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:15
verses.text: To be "baptized for the dead" therefore means, in fact, to be baptized for the body; for, as we have shown, it is the body which becomes dead.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:16
verses.text: What, then, shall they do who are baptized for the body, if the body rises not again? We stand, then, on firm ground (when we say) that the next question which the apostle has discussed equally relates to the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:17
verses.text: But "some man will say, 'How are the dead raised up? With what body do they come?'" Having established the doctrine of the resurrection which was denied, it was natural to discuss what would be the sort of body (in the resurrection), of which no one had an idea.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:18
verses.text: On this point we have other opponents with whom to engage.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:19
verses.text: For Marcion does not in any wise admit the resurrection of the flesh, and it is only the salvation of the soul which he promises; consequently the question which he raises is not concerning the sort of body, but the very substance thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:20
verses.text: Notwithstanding, he is most plainly refuted even from what the apostle advances respecting the quality of the body, in answer to those who ask, "How are the dead raised up? with what body do they come?" For as he treated of the sort of body, he of course ipso facto proclaimed in the argument that it was a body which would rise again.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:21
verses.text: Indeed, since he proposes as his examples "wheat grain, or some other grain, to which God giveth a body, such as it hath pleased Him;" since also he says, that "to every seed is its own body;" that, consequently, "there is one kind of flesh of men, whilst there is another of beasts, and (another) of birds; that there are also celestial bodies and bodies terrestrial; and that there is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars"—does he not therefore intimate that there is to be a resurrection of the flesh or body, which he illustrates by fleshly and corporeal samples? Does he not also guarantee that the resurrection shall be accomplished by that God from whom proceed all the (creatures which have served him for) examples? "So also," says he, "is the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:22
verses.text: How?  Just as the grain, which is sown a body, springs up a body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:23
verses.text: This sowing of the body he called the dissolving thereof in the ground, "because it is sown in corruption," (but "is raised) to honour and power".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:24
verses.text: Now, just as in the case of the grain, so here: to Him will belong the work in the revival of the body, who ordered the process in the dissolution thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:25
verses.text: If, however, you remove the body from the resurrection which you submitted to the dissolution, what becomes of the diversity in the issue? Likewise, "although it is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:26
verses.text: Now, although the natural principle of life and the spirit have each a body proper to itself, so that the "natural body" may fairly be taken to signify the soul, and "the spiritual body" the spirit, yet that is no reason for supposing the apostle to say that the soul is to become spirit in the resurrection, but that the body (which, as being born along with the soul, and as retaining its life by means of the soul, admits of being called animal (or natural) will become spiritual, since it rises through the Spirit to an eternal life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:27
verses.text: In short, since it is not the soul, but the flesh which is "sown in corruption," when it turns to decay in the ground, it follows that (after such dissolution) the soul is no longer the natural body, but the flesh, which was the natural body, (is the subject of the future change), forasmuch as of a natural body it is made a spiritual body, as he says further down, "That was not first which is spiritual".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:28
verses.text: For to this effect he just before remarked of Christ Himself: "The first man Adam was made a living soul, the last Adam was made a quickening spirit".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:29
verses.text: Our heretic, however, in the excess of his folly, being unwilling that the statement should remain in this shape, altered "last Adam" into "last Lord;" because he feared, of course, that if he allowed the Lord to be the last (or second) Adam, we should contend that Christ, being the second Adam, must needs belong to that God who owned also the first Adam.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:30
verses.text: But the falsification is transparent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:31
verses.text: For why is there a first Adam, unless it be that there is also a second Adam? For things are not classed together unless they be severally alike, and have an identity of either name, or substance, or origin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:32
verses.text: Now, although among things which are even individually diverse, one must be first and another last, yet they must have one author.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:33
verses.text: If, however, the author be a different one, he himself indeed may be called the last.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:34
verses.text: But the thing which he introduces is the first, and that only can be the last, which is like this first in nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:35
verses.text: It is, however, not like the first in nature, when it is not the work of the same author.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:36
verses.text: In like manner (the heretic) will be refuted also with the word "man: "  "The first man is of the earth, earthy; the second man is the Lord from heaven".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:37
verses.text: Now, since the first was a man, how can there be a second, unless he is a man also? Or, else, if the second is "Lord," was the first "Lord" also? It is, however, quite enough for me, that in his Gospel he admits the Son of man to be both Christ and Man; so that he will not be able to deny Him (in this passage), in the "Adam" and the "man" (of the apostle).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:38
verses.text: What follows will also be too much for him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:39
verses.text: For when the apostle says, "As is the earthy," that is, man, "such also are they that are earthy"—men again, of course; "therefore as is the heavenly," meaning the Man, from heaven, "such are the men also that are heavenly".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:40
verses.text: For he could not possibly have opposed to earthly men any heavenly beings that were not men also; his object being the more accurately to distinguish their state and expectation by using this name in common for them both.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:41
verses.text: For in respect of their present state and their future expectation he calls men earthly and heavenly, still reserving their parity of name, according as they are reckoned (as to their ultimate condition) in Adam or in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:42
verses.text: Therefore, when exhorting them to cherish the hope of heaven, he says: "As we have borne the image of the earthy, so let us also bear the image of the heavenly,"—language which relates not to any condition of resurrection life, but to the rule of the present time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:43
verses.text: He says, Let us bear, as a precept; not We shall bear, in the sense of a promise—wishing us to walk even as he himself was walking, and to put off the likeness of the earthly, that is, of the old man, in the works of the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:44
verses.text: For what are this next words? "Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:45
verses.text: He means the works of the flesh and blood, which, in his Epistle to the Galatians, deprive men of the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:46
verses.text: In other passages also he is accustomed to put the natural condition instead of the works that are done therein, as when he says, that "they who are in the flesh cannot please God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:47
verses.text: Now, when shall we be able to please God except whilst we are in this flesh?  There is, I imagine, no other time wherein a man can work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:48
verses.text: If, however, whilst we are even naturally living in the flesh, we yet eschew the deeds of the flesh, then we shall not be in the flesh; since, although we are not absent from the substance of the flesh, we are notwithstanding strangers to the sin thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:49
verses.text: Now, since in the word flesh we are enjoined to put off, not the substance, but the works of the flesh, therefore in the use of the same word the kingdom of God is denied to the works of the flesh, not to the substance thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:50
verses.text: For not that is condemned in which evil is done, but only the evil which is done in it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:51
verses.text: To administer poison is a crime, but the cup in which it is given is not guilty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:52
verses.text: So the body is the vessel of the works of the flesh, whilst the soul which is within it mixes the poison of a wicked act.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:53
verses.text: How then is it, that the soul, which is the real author of the works of the flesh, shall attain to the kingdom of God, after the deeds done in the body have been atoned for, whilst the body, which was nothing but (the soul's) ministering agent, must remain in condemnation? Is the cup to be punished, but the poisoner to escape?  Not that we indeed claim the kingdom of God for the flesh: all we do is, to assert a resurrection for the substance thereof, as the gate of the kingdom through which it is entered.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:54
verses.text: But the resurrection is one thing, and the kingdom is another.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:55
verses.text: The resurrection is first, and afterwards the kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:56
verses.text: We say, therefore, that the flesh rises again, but that when changed it obtains the kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:57
verses.text: "For the dead shall be raised incorruptible," even those who had been corruptible when their bodies fell into decay; "and we shall be changed, in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:58
verses.text: For this corruptible"—and as he spake, the apostle seemingly pointed to his own flesh—"must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality," in order, indeed, that it may be rendered a fit substance for the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:59
verses.text: "For we shall be like the angels".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:60
verses.text: This will be the perfect change of our flesh—only after its resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:61
verses.text: Now if, on the contrary, there is to be no flesh, how then shall it put on incorruption and immortality? Having then become something else by its change, it will obtain the kingdom of God, no longer the (old) flesh and blood, but the body which God shall have given it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:62
verses.text: Rightly then does the apostle declare, "Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God;" for this (honour) does he ascribe to the changed condition which ensues on the resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:63
verses.text: Since, therefore, shall then be accomplished the word which was written by the Creator, "O death, where is thy victory"—or thy struggle? "O death, where is thy sting?"—written, I say, by the Creator, for He wrote them by His prophet—to Him will belong the gift, that is, the kingdom, who proclaimed the word which is to be accomplished in the kingdom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 10:64
verses.text: And to none other God does he tell us that "thanks" are due, for having enabled us to achieve "the victory" even over death, than to Him from whom he received the very expression of the exulting and triumphant challenge to the mortal foe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:1
verses.text: The Second Epistle to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:2
verses.text: The Creator the Father of Mercies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:3
verses.text: Shown to Be Such in the Old Testament, and Also in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:4
verses.text: The Newness of the New Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:5
verses.text: The Veil of Obdurate Blindness Upon Israel, Not Reprehensible on Marcion's Principles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:6
verses.text: The Jews Guilty in Rejecting the Christ of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:7
verses.text: Satan, the God of This World.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:8
verses.text: The Treasure in Earthen Vessels Explained Against Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:9
verses.text: The Creator's Relation to These Vessels, i-e: Our Bodies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:10
verses.text: If, owing to the fault of human error, the word God has become a common name (since in the world there are said and believed to be "gods many"), yet "the blessed God," (who is "the Father) of our Lord Jesus Christ," will be understood to be no other God than the Creator, who both blessed all things (that He had made), as you find in Genesis, and is Himself "blessed by all things," as Daniel tells us.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:11
verses.text: Now, if the title of Father may be claimed for (Marcion's) sterile god, how much more for the Creator? To none other than Him is it suitable, who is also "the Father of mercies," and (in the prophets) has been described as "full of compassion, and gracious, and plenteous in mercy".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:12
verses.text: In Jonah you find the signal act of His mercy, which He showed to the praying Ninevites.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:13
verses.text: How inflexible was He at the tears of Hezekiah! How ready to forgive Ahab, the husband of Jezebel, the blood of Naboth, when he deprecated His anger.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:14
verses.text: How prompt in pardoning David on his confession of his sin—preferring, indeed, the sinner's repentance to his death, of course because of His gracious attribute of mercy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:15
verses.text: Now, if Marcion's god has exhibited or proclaimed any such thing as this, I will allow him to be "the Father of mercies".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:16
verses.text: Since, however, he ascribes to him this title only from the time he has been revealed, as if he were the father of mercies from the time only when he began to liberate the human race, then we on our side, too, adopt the same precise date of his alleged revelation; but it is that we may deny him! It is then not competent to him to ascribe any quality to his god, whom indeed he only promulged by the fact of such an ascription; for only if it were previously evident that his god had an existence, could he be permitted to ascribe an attribute to him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:17
verses.text: The ascribed attribute is only an accident; but accidents are preceded by the statement of the thing itself of which they are predicated, especially when another claims the attribute which is ascribed to him who has not been previously shown to exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:18
verses.text: Our denial of his existence will be all the more peremptory, because of the fact that the attribute which is alleged in proof of it belongs to that God who has been already revealed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:19
verses.text: Therefore "the New Testament" will appertain to none other than Him who promised it—if not "its letter, yet its spirit;" and herein will lie its newness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:20
verses.text: Indeed, He who had engraved its letter in stones is the same as He who had said of its spirit, "I will pour out of my Spirit upon all flesh".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:21
verses.text: Even if "the letter killeth, yet the Spirit giveth life;" and both belong to Him who says: "I kill, and I make alive; I wound, and I heal".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:22
verses.text: We have already made good the Creator's claim to this twofold character of judgment and goodness—"killing in the letter" through the law, and "quickening in the Spirit" through the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:23
verses.text: Now these attributes, however different they be, cannot possibly make two gods; for they have already (in the prevenient dispensation of the Old Testament) been found to meet in One.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:24
verses.text: He alludes to Moses' veil, covered with which "his face could not be stedfastly seen by the children of Israel".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:25
verses.text: Since he did this to maintain the superiority of the glory of the New Testament, which is permanent in its glory, over that of the Old, "which was to be done away," this fact gives support to my belief which exalts the Gospel above the law and you must look well to it that it does not even more than this.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:26
verses.text: For only there is superiority possible where was previously the thing over which superiority can be affirmed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:27
verses.text: But then he says, "But their minds were blinded"—of the world; certainly not the Creator's mind, but the minds of the people which are in the world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:28
verses.text: Of Israel he says, Even unto this day the same veil is upon their heart;" showing that the veil which was on the face of Moses was a figure of the veil which is on the heart of the nation still; because even now Moses is not seen by them in heart, just as he was not then seen by them in eye.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:29
verses.text: But what concern has Paul with the veil which still obscures Moses from their view, if the Christ of the Creator, whom Moses predicted, is not yet come? How are the hearts of the Jews represented as still covered and veiled, if the predictions of Moses relating to Christ, in whom it was their duty to believe through him, are as yet unfulfilled? What had the apostle of a strange Christ to complain of, if the Jews failed in understanding the mysterious announcements of their own God, unless the veil which was upon their hearts had reference to that blindness which concealed from their eyes the Christ of Moses? Then, again, the words which follow, But when it shall turn to the Lord, the evil shall be taken away," properly refer to the Jew, over whose gaze Moses' veil is spread, to the effect that, when he is turned to the faith of Christ, he will understand how Moses spoke of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:30
verses.text: But how shall the veil of the Creator be taken away by the Christ of another god, whose mysteries the Creator could not possibly have veiled—unknown mysteries, as they were of an unknown god? So he says that "we now with open face" (meaning the candour of the heart, which in the Jews had been covered with a veil), "beholding Christ, are changed into the same image, from that glory" (wherewith Moses was transfigured as by the glory of the Lord) "to another glory".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:31
verses.text: By thus setting forth the glory which illumined the person of Moses from his interview with God, and the veil which concealed the same from the infirmity of the people, and by superinducing thereupon the revelation and the glory of the Spirit in the person of Christ—"even as," to use his words, "by the Spirit of the Lord"—he testifies that the whole Mosaic system was a figure of Christ, of whom the Jews indeed were ignorant, but who is known to us Christians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:32
verses.text: We are quite aware that some passages are open to ambiguity, from the way in which they are read, or else from their punctuation, when there is room for these two causes of ambiguity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:33
verses.text: The latter method has been adopted by Marcion, by reading the passage which follows, "in whom the God of this world," as if it described the Creator as the God of this world, in order that he may, by these words, imply that there is another God for the other world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:34
verses.text: We, however, say that the passage ought to be punctuated with a comma after God, to this effect: "In whom God hath blinded the eyes of the unbelievers of this world".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:35
verses.text: "In whom" means the Jewish unbelievers, from some of whom the gospel is still hidden under Moses' veil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:36
verses.text: Now it is these whom God had threatened for "loving Him indeed with the lip, whilst their heart was far from Him," in these angry words: "Ye shall hear with your ears, and not understand; and see with your eyes, but not perceive;" and, "If ye will not believe, ye shall not understand;" and again, "I will take away the wisdom of their wise men, and bring to nought the understanding of their prudent ones".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:37
verses.text: But these words, of course, He did not pronounce against them for concealing the gospel of the unknown God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:38
verses.text: At any rate, if there is a God of this world, He blinds the heart of the unbelievers of this world, because they have not of their own accord recognised His Christ, who ought to be understood from His Scriptures.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:39
verses.text: Content with my advantage, I can willingly refrain from noticing to any greater length this point of ambiguous punctuation, so as not to give my adversary any advantage, indeed, I might have wholly omitted the discussion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:40
verses.text: A simpler answer I shall find ready to hand in interpreting "the god of this world" of the devil, who once said, as the prophet describes him: "I will be like the Most High; I will exalt my throne in the clouds".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:41
verses.text: The whole superstition, indeed, of this world has got into his hands, so that he blinds effectually the hearts of unbelievers, and of none more than the apostate Marcion's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:42
verses.text: Now he did not observe how much this clause of the sentence made against him: "For God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts, to (give) the light of the knowledge (of His glory) in the face of (Jesus) Christ".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:43
verses.text: Now who was it that said; "Let there be light?" And who was it that said to Christ concerning giving light to the world: "I have set Thee as a light to the Gentiles"—to them, that is, "who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death?" (None else, surely, than He), to whom the Spirit in the Psalm answers, in His foresight of the future, saying, "The light of Thy countenance, O Lord, hath been displayed upon us".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:44
verses.text: Now the countenance (or person) of the Lord here is Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:45
verses.text: Wherefore the apostle said above: "Christ, who is the image of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:46
verses.text: Since Christ, then, is the person of the Creator, who said, "Let there be light," it follows that Christ and the apostles, and the gospel, and the veil, and Moses—nay, the whole of the dispensations—belong to the God who is the Creator of this world, according to the testimony of the clause (above adverted to), and certainly not to him who never said, "Let there be light".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:47
verses.text: I here pass over discussion about another epistle, which we hold to have been written to the Ephesians, but the heretics to the Laodiceans.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:48
verses.text: In it he tells them to remember, that at the time when they were Gentiles they were without Christ, aliens from (the commonwealth of) Israel, without intercourse, without the covenants and any hope of promise, nay, without God, even in his own world, as the Creator thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:49
verses.text: Since therefore he said, that the Gentiles were without God, whilst their god was the devil, not the Creator, it is clear that he must be understood to be the lord of this world, whom the Gentiles received as their god—not the Creator, of whom they were in ignorance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:50
verses.text: But how does it happen, that "the treasure which we have in these earthen vessels of ours" should not be regarded as belonging to the God who owns the vessels? Now since God's glory is, that so great a treasure is contained in earthen vessels, and since these earthen vessels are of the Creator's make, it follows that the glory is the Creator's; nay, since these vessels of His smack so much of the excellency of the power of God, that power itself must be His also! Indeed, all these things have been consigned to the said "earthen vessels" for the very purpose that His excellence might be manifested forth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:51
verses.text: Henceforth, then, the rival god will have no claim to the glory, and consequently none to the power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:52
verses.text: Rather, dishonour and weakness will accrue to him, because the earthen vessels with which he had nothing to do have received all the excellency! Well, then, if it be in these very earthen vessels that he tells us we have to endure so great sufferings, in which we bear about with us the very dying of God, (Marcion's) god is really ungrateful and unjust, if he does not mean to restore this same substance of ours at the resurrection, wherein so much has been endured in loyalty to him, in which Christ's very death is borne about, wherein too the excellency of his power is treasured.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:53
verses.text: For he gives prominence to the statement, "That the life also of Christ may be manifested in our body," as a contrast to the preceding, that His death is borne about in our body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:54
verses.text: Now of what life of Christ does he here speak?  Of that which we are now living?  Then how is it, that in the words which follow he exhorts us not to the things which are seen and are temporal, but to those which are not seen and are eternal—in other words, not to the present, but to the future? But if it be of the future life of Christ that he speaks, intimating that it is to be made manifest in our body, then he has clearly predicted the resurrection of the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:55
verses.text: He says, too, that "our outward man perishes," not meaning by an eternal perdition after death, but by labours and sufferings, in reference to which he previously said, "For which cause we will not faint".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 11:56
verses.text: Now, when he adds of "the inward man" also, that it "is renewed day by day," he demonstrates both issues here—the wasting away of the body by the wear and tear of its trials, and the renewal of the soul by its contemplation of the promises.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:1
verses.text: The Eternal Home in Heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:2
verses.text: Beautiful Exposition by Tertullian of the Apostle's Consolatory Teaching Against the Fear of Death, So Apt to Arise Under Anti-Christian Oppression.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:3
verses.text: The Judgment-Seat of Christ—The Idea, Anti-Marcionite.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:4
verses.text: Paradise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:5
verses.text: Judicial Characteristics of Christ Which are Inconsistent with the Heretical Views About Him; The Apostle's Sharpness, or Severity, Shows Him to Be a Fit Preacher of the Creator's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:6
verses.text: As to the house of this our earthly dwelling-place, when he says that "we have an eternal home in heaven, not made with hands," he by no means would imply that, because it was built by the Creator's hand, it must perish in a perpetual dissolution after death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:7
verses.text: He treats of this subject in order to offer consolation against the fear of death and the dread of this very dissolution, as is even more manifest from what follows, when he adds, that "in this tabernacle of our earthly body we do groan, earnestly desiring to be clothed upon with the vesture which is from heaven, if so be, that having been unclothed, we shall not be found naked;" in other words, shall regain that of which we have been divested, even our body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:8
verses.text: And again he says: "We that are in this tabernacle do groan, not as if we were oppressed with an unwillingness to be unclothed, but (we wish) to be clothed upon".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:9
verses.text: He here says expressly, what he touched but lightly in his first epistle, where he wrote:)  "The dead shall be raised incorruptible (meaning those who had undergone mortality), "and we shall be changed" (whom God shall find to be yet in the flesh).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:10
verses.text: Both those shall be raised incorruptible, because they shall regain their body—and that a renewed one, from which shall come their incorruptibility; and these also shall, in the crisis of the last moment, and from their instantaneous death, whilst encountering the oppressions of anti-christ, undergo a change, obtaining therein not so much a divestiture of body as "a clothing upon" with the vesture which is from heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:11
verses.text: So that whilst these shall put on over their (changed) body this, heavenly raiment, the dead also shall for their part recover their body, over which they too have a supervesture to put on, even the incorruption of heaven; because of these it was that he said:  "This corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:12
verses.text: The one put on this (heavenly) apparel, when they recover their bodies; the others put it on as a supervesture, when they indeed hardly lose them (in the suddenness of their change).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:13
verses.text: It was accordingly not without good reason that he described them as "not wishing indeed to be unclothed," but (rather as wanting) "to be clothed upon;" in other words, as wishing not to undergo death, but to be surprised into life, "that this moral (body) might be swallowed up of life," by being rescued from death in the supervesture of its changed state.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:14
verses.text: This is why he shows us how much better it is for us not to be sorry, if we should be surprised by death, and tells us that we even hold of God "the earnest of His Spirit" (pledged as it were thereby to have "the clothing upon," which is the object of our hope), and that "so long as we are in the flesh, we are absent from the Lord;" moreover, that we ought on this account to prefer "rather to be absent from the body and to be present with the Lord," and so to be ready to meet even death with joy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:15
verses.text: In this view it is that he informs us how "we must all appear before the judgement-seat of Christ, that every one may receive the things done in his body, according as he hath done either good or bad".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:16
verses.text: Since, however, there is then to be a retribution according to men's merits, how will any be able to reckon with God? But by mentioning both the judgment-seat and the distinction between works good and bad, he sets before us a Judge who is to award both sentences, and has thereby affirmed that all will have to be present at the tribunal in their bodies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:17
verses.text: For it will be impossible to pass sentence except on the body, for what has been done in the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:18
verses.text: God would be unjust, if any one were not punished or else rewarded in that very condition, wherein the merit was itself achieved.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:19
verses.text: "If therefore any man be in Christ, he is a new creature; old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new;" and so is accomplished the prophecy of Isaiah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:20
verses.text: When also he (in a later passage) enjoins us "to cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of flesh and blood" (since this substance enters not the kingdom of God); when, again, he "espouses the church as a chaste virgin to Christ," a spouse to a spouse in very deed, an image cannot be combined and compared with what is opposed to the real nature of the thing (with which it is compared).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:21
verses.text: So when he designates "false apostles, deceitful workers transforming themselves" into likenesses of himself, of course by their hypocrisy, he charges them with the guilt of disorderly conversation, rather than of false doctrine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:22
verses.text: The contrariety, therefore, was one of conduct, not of gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:23
verses.text: If "Satan himself, too, is transformed into an angel of light," such an assertion must not be used to the prejudice of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:24
verses.text: The Creator is not an angel, but God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:25
verses.text: Into a god of light, and not an angel of light, must Satan then have been said to be transformed, if he did not mean to call him "the angel," which both we and Marcion know him to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:26
verses.text: On Paradise is the title of a treatise of ours, in which is discussed all that the subject admits of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:27
verses.text: I shall here simply wonder, in connection with this matter, whether a god who has no dispensation of any kind on earth could possibly have a paradise to call his own—without perchance availing himself of the paradise of the Creator, to use it as he does His world—much in the character of a mendicant.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:28
verses.text: And yet of the removal of a man from earth to heaven we have an instance afforded us by the Creator in Elijah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:29
verses.text: But what will excite my surprise still more is the case (next supposed by Marcion), that a God so good and gracious, and so averse to blows and cruelty, should have suborned the angel Satan—not his own either, but the Creator's—"to buffet" the apostle, and then to have refused his request, when thrice entreated to liberate him! It would seem, therefore, that Marcion's god imitates the Creator's conduct, who is an enemy to the proud, even "putting down the mighty from their seats".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 12:30
verses.text: Is he then the same God as He who gave Satan power over the person of Job that his "strength might be made perfect in weakness?" How is it that the censurer of the Galatians still retains the very formula of the law:  "In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established?" How again is it that he threatens sinners "that he will not spare" them—he, the preacher of a most gentle god? Yea, he even declares that "the Lord hath given to him the power of using sharpness in their presence!" Deny now, O heretic, (at your cost,) that your god is an object to be feared, when his apostle was for making himself so formidable!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:1
verses.text: The Epistle to the Romans.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:3
verses.text: Paul Cannot Help Using Phrases Which Bespeak the Justice of God, Even When He is Eulogizing the Mercies of the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:4
verses.text: Marcion Particularly Hard in Mutilation of This Epistle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:5
verses.text: Yet Our Author Argues on Common Ground.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:6
verses.text: The Judgment at Last Will Be in Accordance with the Gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:7
verses.text: The Justified by Faith Exhorted to Have Peace with God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:8
verses.text: The Administration of the Old and the New Dispensations in One and the Same Hand.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:9
verses.text: Since my little work is approaching its termination, I must treat but briefly the points which still occur, whilst those which have so often turned up must be put aside.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:10
verses.text: I regret still to have to contend about the law—after I have so often proved that its replacement (by the gospel) affords no argument for another god, predicted as it was indeed in Christ, and in the Creator's own plans ordained for His Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:11
verses.text: (But I must revert to that discussion) so far as (the apostle leads me, for) this very epistle looks very much as if it abrogated the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:12
verses.text: We have, however, often shown before now that God is declared by the apostle to be a Judge; and that in the Judge is implied an Avenger; and in the Avenger, the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:13
verses.text: And so in the passage where he says: "I am not ashamed of the gospel (of Christ): for it is the power of god unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek; for therein is the righteousness of God revealed from faith to faith," he undoubtedly ascribes both the gospel and salvation to Him whom (in accordance with our heretic's own distinction) I have called the just God, not the good one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:14
verses.text: It is He who removes (men) from confidence in the law to faith in the gospel—that is to say, His own law and His own gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:15
verses.text: When, again, he declares that "the wrath (of God) is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who hold the truth in unrighteousness," (I ask) the wrath of what God? Of the Creator certainly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:16
verses.text: The truth, therefore, will be His, whose is also the wrath, which has to be revealed to avenge the truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 13:17
