verses.text: The Divine Power Shown in Christ's Incarnation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:2
verses.text: Meaning of St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:3
verses.text: Paul's Phrase.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:4
verses.text: Likeness of Sinful Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:5
verses.text: No Docetism in It.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:6
verses.text: Resurrection of Our Real Bodies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:7
verses.text: A Wide Chasm Made in the Epistle by Marcion's Erasure.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:8
verses.text: When the Jews are Upbraided by the Apostle for Their Misconduct to God; Inasmuch as that God Was the Creator, a Proof is in Fact Given that St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:9
verses.text: Paul's God Was the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:10
verses.text: The Precepts at the End of the Epistle, Which Marcion Allowed, Shown to Be in Exact Accordance with the Creator's Scriptures.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:11
verses.text: If the Father "sent His Son in the likeness of sinful flesh," it must not therefore be said that the flesh which He seemed to have was but a phantom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:12
verses.text: For he in a previous verse ascribed sin to the flesh, and made it out to be "the law of sin dwelling in his members," and "warring against the law of the mind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:13
verses.text: On this account, therefore, (does he mean to say that) the Son was sent in the likeness of sinful flesh, that He might redeem this sinful flesh by a like substance, even a fleshly one, which bare a resemblance to sinful flesh, although it was itself free from sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:14
verses.text: Now this will be the very perfection of divine power to effect the salvation (of man) in a nature like his own.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:15
verses.text: For it would be no great matter if the Spirit of God remedied the flesh; but when a flesh, which is the very copy of the sinning substance—itself flesh also—only without sin, (effects the remedy, then doubtless it is a great thing).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:16
verses.text: The likeness, therefore, will have reference to the quality of the sinfulness, and not to any falsity of the substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:17
verses.text: Because he would not have added the attribute "sinful," if he meant the "likeness" to be so predicated of the substance as to deny the verity thereof; in that case he would only have used the word "flesh," and omitted the "sinful".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:18
verses.text: But inasmuch as he has put the two together, and said "sinful flesh," (or "flesh of sin,") he has both affirmed the substance, that is, the flesh and referred the likeness to the fault of the substance, that is, to its sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:19
verses.text: But even suppose that the likeness was predicated of the substance, the truth of the said substance will not be thereby denied.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:20
verses.text: Why then call the true substance like? Because it is indeed true, only not of a seed of like condition with our own; but true still, as being of a nature not really unlike ours.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:21
verses.text: And again, in contrary things there is no likeness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:22
verses.text: Thus the likeness of flesh would not be called spirit, because flesh is not susceptible of any likeness to spirit; but it would be called phantom, if it seemed to be that which it really was not.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:23
verses.text: It is, however, called likeness, since it is what it seems to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:24
verses.text: Now it is (what it seems to be), because it is on a par with the other thing (with which it is compared).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:25
verses.text: But a phantom, which is merely such and nothing else, is not a likeness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:26
verses.text: The apostle, however, himself here comes to our aid; for, while explaining in what sense he would not have us "live in the flesh," although in the flesh—even by not living in the works of the flesh—he shows that when he wrote the words, "Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God," it was not with the view of condemning the substance (of the flesh), but the works thereof; and because it is possible for these not to be committed by us whilst we are still in the flesh, they will therefore be properly chargeable, not on the substance of the flesh, but on its conduct.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:27
verses.text: Likewise, if "the body indeed is dead because of sin" (from which statement we see that not the death of the soul is meant, but that of the body), "but the spirit is life because of righteousness," it follows that this life accrues to that which incurred death because of sin, that is, as we have just seen, the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:28
verses.text: Now the bodyis only restored to him who had lost it; so that the resurrection of the dead implies the resurrection of their bodies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:29
verses.text: He accordingly subjoins: "He that raised up Christ from the dead, shall also quicken your mortal bodies".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:30
verses.text: In these words he both affirmed the resurrection of the flesh (without which nothing can rightly be called body, nor can anything be properly regarded as mortal), and proved the bodily substance of Christ; inasmuch as our own mortal bodies will be quickened in precisely the same way as He was raised; and that was in no other way than in the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:31
verses.text: I have here a very wide gulf of expunged Scripture to leap across; however, I alight on the place where the apostle bears record of Israel "that they have a zeal of God"—their own God, of course—"but not according to knowledge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:32
verses.text: For," says he, "being ignorant of (the righteousness of) God, and going about to establish their own righteousness, they have not submitted themselves unto the righteousness of God; for Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:33
verses.text: Hereupon we shall be confronted with an argument of the heretic, that the Jews were ignorant of the superior God, since, in opposition to him, they set up their own righteousness—that is, the righteousness of their law—not receiving Christ, the end (or finisher) of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:34
verses.text: But how then is it that he bears testimony to their zeal for their own God, if it is not in respect of the same God that he upbraids them for their ignorance?  They were affected indeed with zeal for God, but it was not an intelligent zeal: they were, in fact, ignorant of Him, because they were ignorant of His dispensations by Christ, who was to bring about the consummation of the law; and in this way did they maintain their own righteousness in opposition to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:35
verses.text: But so does the Creator Himself testify to their ignorance concerning Him: "Israel hath not known me; my people have not understood me;" and as to their preferring the establishment of their own righteousness, (the Creator again describes them as) "teaching for doctrines the commandments of men;" moreover, as "having gathered themselves together against the Lord and against His Christ"—from ignorance of Him, of course.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:36
verses.text: Now nothing can be expounded of another god which is applicable to the Creator; otherwise the apostle would not have been just in reproaching the Jews with ignorance in respect of a god of whom they knew nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:37
verses.text: For where had been their sin, if they only maintained the righteousness of their own God against one of whom they were ignorant? But he exclaims: "O the depth of the riches and the wisdom of God; how unsearchable also are His ways!" Whence this outburst of feeling? Surely from the recollection of the Scriptures, which he had been previously turning over, as well as from his contemplation of the mysteries which he had been setting forth above, in relation to the faith of Christ coming from the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:38
verses.text: If Marcion had an object in his erasures, why does his apostle utter such an exclamation, because his god has no riches for him to contemplate? So poor and indigent was he, that he created nothing, predicted nothing—in short, possessed nothing; for it was into the world of another God that he descended.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:39
verses.text: The truth is, the Creator's resources and riches, which once had been hidden, were now disclosed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:40
verses.text: For so had He promised: "I will give to them treasures which have been hidden, and which men have not seen will I open to them".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:41
verses.text: Hence, then, came the exclamation, "O the depth of the riches and the wisdom of God!" For His treasures were now opening out.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:42
verses.text: This is the purport of what Isaiah said, and of (the apostle's own) subsequent quotation of the self-same passage, of the prophet: "Who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been His counsellor? Who hath first given to Him, and it shall be recompensed to him again?" Now, (Marcion,) since you have expunged so much from the Scriptures, why did you retain these words, as if they too were not the Creator's words? But come now, let us see without mistake the precepts of your new god: "Abhor that which is evil, and cleave to that which is good".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:43
verses.text: Well, is the precept different in the Creator's teaching? "Take away the evil from you, depart from it, and be doing good".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:44
verses.text: Then again: "Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:45
verses.text: Now is not this of the same import as: "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thy self?" (Again, your apostle says:) "Rejoicing in hope;" that is, of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:46
verses.text: So says the Creator's Psalmist:  "It is better to hope in the Lord, than to hope even in princes".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:47
verses.text: "Patient in tribulation".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:48
verses.text: You have (this in) the Psalm: "The Lord hear thee in the day of tribulation".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:49
verses.text: "Bless, and curse not," (says your apostle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:50
verses.text: ) But what better teacher of this will you find than Him who created all things, and blessed them? "Mind not high things, but condescend to men of low estate.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:51
verses.text: Be not wise in your own conceits".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:52
verses.text: For against such a disposition Isaiah pronounces a woe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:53
verses.text: "Recompense to no man evil for evil".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:54
verses.text: (Like unto which is the Creator's precept:) "Thou shalt not remember thy brother's evil against thee".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:55
verses.text: (Again:)  "Avenge not yourselves;" for it is written, "Vengeance is mine, I will repay, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:56
verses.text: "Live peaceably with all men".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:57
verses.text: The retaliation of the law, therefore, permitted not retribution for an injury; it rather repressed any attempt thereat by the fear of a recompense.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:58
verses.text: Very properly, then, did he sum up the entire teaching of the Creator in this precept of His: "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:59
verses.text: Now, if this is the recapitulation of the law from the very law itself, I am at a loss to know who is the God of the law.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:60
verses.text: I fear He must be Marcion's god (after all).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:61
verses.text: If also the gospel of Christ is fulfilled in this same precept, but not the Creator's Christ, what is the use of our contending any longer whether Christ did or did not say, "I am not come to destroy the law, but to fulfil it?" In vain has (our man of) Pontus laboured to deny this statement.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:62
verses.text: If the gospel has not fulfilled the law, then all I can say is, the law has fulfilled the gospel.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:63
verses.text: But it is well that in a later verse he threatens us with "the judgment-seat of Christ,"—the Judge, of course, and the Avenger, and therefore the Creator's (Christ).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 14:64
verses.text: This Creator, too, however much he may preach up another god, he certainly sets forth for us as a Being to be served, if he holds Him thus up as an object to be feared.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:1
verses.text: The First Epistle to the Thessalonians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:2
verses.text: The Shorter Epistles Pungent in Sense and Very Valuable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:3
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:4
verses.text: Paul Upbraids the Jews for the Death First of Their Prophets and Then of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:5
verses.text: This a Presumption that Both Christ and the Prophets Pertained to the Same God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:6
verses.text: The Law of Nature, Which is in Fact the Creator's Discipline, and the Gospel of Christ Both Enjoin Chastity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:7
verses.text: The Resurrection Provided for in the Old Testament by Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:8
verses.text: Man's Compound Nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:9
verses.text: I shall not be sorry to bestow attention on the shorter epistles also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:10
verses.text: Even in brief works there is much pungency.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:11
verses.text: The Jews had slain their prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:12
verses.text: I may ask, What has this to do with the apostle of the rival god, one so amiable withal, who could hardly be said to condemn even the failings of his own people; and who, moreover, has himself some hand in making away with the same prophets whom he is destroying? What injury did Israel commit against him in slaying those whom he too has reprobated, since he was the first to pass a hostile sentence on them? But Israel sinned against their own God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:13
verses.text: He upbraided their iniquity to whom the injured God pertains; and certainly he is anything but the adversary of the injured Deity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:14
verses.text: Else he would not have burdened them with the charge of killing even the Lord, in the words, "Who both killed the Lord Jesus and their own prophets," although (the pronoun) their own be an addition of the heretics.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:15
verses.text: Now, what was there so very acrimonious in their killing Christ the proclaimer of the new god, after they had put to death also the prophets of their own god?  The fact, however, of their having slain the Lord and His servants, is put as a case of climax.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:16
verses.text: Now, if it were the Christ of one god and the prophets of another god whom they slew, he would certainly have placed the impious crimes on the same level, instead of mentioning them in the way of a climax; but they did not admit of being put on the same level: the climax, therefore, was only possible by the sin having been in fact committed against one and the same Lord in the two respective circumstances.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:17
verses.text: To one and the same Lord, then, belonged Christ and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:18
verses.text: What that "sanctification of ours" is, which he declares to be "the will of God," you may discover from the opposite conduct which he forbids.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:19
verses.text: That we should "abstain from fornication," not from marriage; that every one "should know how to possess his vessel in honour".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:20
verses.text: In what way?  "Not in the lust of concupiscence, even as the Gentiles".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:21
verses.text: Concupiscence, however, is not ascribed to marriage even among the Gentiles, but to extravagant, unnatural, and enormous sins.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:22
verses.text: The law of nature is opposed to luxury as well as to grossness and uncleanness; it does not forbid connubial intercourse, but concupiscence; and it takes care of our vessel by the honourable estate of matrimony.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:23
verses.text: This passage (of the apostle) I would treat in such a way as to maintain the superiority of the other and higher sanctity, preferring continence and virginity to marriage, but by no means prohibiting the latter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:24
verses.text: For my hostility is directed against those who are for destroying the God of marriage, not those who follow after chastity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:25
verses.text: He says that those who "remain unto the coming of Christ," along with "the dead in Christ, shall rise first," being "caught up in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:26
verses.text: I find it was in their foresight of all this, that the heavenly intelligences gazed with admiration on "the Jerusalem which is above," and by the mouth of Isaiah said long ago:  "Who are these that fly as clouds, and as doves with their young ones, unto me?" Now, as Christ has prepared for us this ascension into heaven, He must be the Christ of whom Amos spoke: "It is He who builds His ascent up to the heavens," even for Himself and His people.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:27
verses.text: Now, from whom shall I expect (the fulfilment of) all this, except from Him whom I have heard give the promise thereof?  What "spirit" does he forbid us to "quench," and what "prophesyings" to "despise?" Not the Creator's spirit, nor the Creator's prophesyings, Marcion of course replies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:28
verses.text: For he has already quenched and despised the thing which he destroys, and is unable to forbid what he has despised.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:29
verses.text: It is then incumbent on Marcion now to display in his church that spirit of his god which must not be quenched, and the prophesyings which must not be despised.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:30
verses.text: And since he has made such a display as he thinks fit, let him know that we shall challenge it whatever it may be to the rule of the grace and power of the Spirit and the prophets—namely, to foretell the future, to reveal the secrets of the heart, and to explain mysteries.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:31
verses.text: And when he shall have failed to produce and give proof of any such criterion, we will then on our side bring out both the Spirit and the prophecies of the Creator, which utter predictions according to His will.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:32
verses.text: Thus it will be clearly seen of what the apostle spoke, even of those things which were to happen in the church of his God; and as long as He endures, so long also does His Spirit work, and so long are His promises repeated.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:33
verses.text: Come now, you who deny the salvation of the flesh, and who, whenever there occurs the specific mention of body in a case of this sort, interpret it as meaning anything rather than the substance of the flesh, (tell me) how is it that the apostle has given certain distinct names to all (our faculties), and has comprised them all in one prayer for their safety, desiring that our "spirit and soul and body may be preserved blameless unto the coming of our Lord and Saviour (Jesus) Christ?" Now he has here propounded the soul and the body as two several and distinct things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:34
verses.text: For although the soul has a kind of body of a quality of its own, just as the spirit has, yet as the soul and the body are distinctly named, the soul has its own peculiar appellation, not requiring the common designation of body.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:35
verses.text: This is left for "the flesh," which having no proper name (in this passage), necessarily makes use of the common designation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:36
verses.text: Indeed, I see no other substance in man, after spirit and soul, to which the term body can be applied except "the flesh".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:37
verses.text: This, therefore, I understand to be meant by the word "body"—as often as the latter is not specifically named.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 15:38
verses.text: Much more do I so understand it in the present passage, where the flesh is expressly called by the name "body".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:1
verses.text: The Second Epistle to the Thessalonians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:2
verses.text: An Absurd Erasure of Marcion; Its Object Transparent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:3
verses.text: The Final Judgment on the Heathen as Well as the Jews Could Not Be Administered by Marcion's Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:4
verses.text: The Man of Sin—What? Inconsistency of Marcion's View.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:5
verses.text: The Antichrist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:6
verses.text: The Great Events of the Last Apostasy Within the Providence and Intention of the Creator, Whose are All Things from the Beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:7
verses.text: Similarity of the Pauline Precepts with Those of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:8
verses.text: We are obliged from time to time to recur to certain topics in order to affirm truths which are connected with them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:9
verses.text: We repeat then here, that as the Lord is by the apostle proclaimed as the awarder of both weal and woe, He must be either the Creator, or (as Marcion would be loth to admit) One like the Creator—"with whom it is a righteous thing to recompense tribulation to them who afflict us, and to ourselves, who are afflicted, rest, when the Lord Jesus shall be revealed as coming from heaven with the angels of His might and in flaming fire".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:10
verses.text: The heretic, however, has erased the flaming fire, no doubt that he might extinguish all traces herein of our own God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:11
verses.text: But the folly of the obliteration is clearly seen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:12
verses.text: For as the apostle declares that the Lord will come "to take vengeance on them that know not God and that obey not the gospel, who," he says, "shall be punished with everlasting destruction from the presence of the Lord, and from the glory of His power"—it follows that, as He comes to inflict punishment, He must require "the flaming fire".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:13
verses.text: Thus on this consideration too we must, notwithstanding Marcion's opposition, conclude that Christ belongs to a God who kindles the flames (of vengeance), and therefore to the Creator, inasmuch as He takes vengeance on such as know not the Lord, that is, on the heathen.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:14
verses.text: For he has mentioned separately "those who obey not the gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ," whether they be sinners among Christians or among Jews.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:15
verses.text: Now, to inflict punishment on the heathen, who very likely have never heard of the Gospel, is not the function of that God who is naturally unknown, and who is revealed nowhere else than in the Gospel, and therefore cannot be known by all men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:16
verses.text: The Creator, however, ought to be known even by (the light of) nature, for He may be understood from His works, and may thereby become the object of a more widely spread knowledge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:17
verses.text: To Him, therefore, does it appertain to punish such as know not God, for none ought to be ignorant of Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:18
verses.text: In the (apostle's) phrase, "From the presence of the Lord, and from the glory of His power," he uses the words of Isaiah who for the express reason makes the self-same Lord "arise to shake terribly the earth".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:19
verses.text: Well, but who is the man of sin, the son of perdition," who must first be revealed before the Lord comes; "who opposeth and exalteth himself above all that is called God, or that is worshipped; who is to sit in the temple of God, and boast himself as being God?" According indeed to our view, he is Antichrist; as it is taught us in both the ancient and the new prophecies, and especially by the Apostle John, who says that "already many false prophets are gone out into the world," the fore-runners of Antichrist, who deny that Christ is come in the flesh, and do not acknowledge Jesus (to be the Christ), meaning in God the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:20
verses.text: According, however, to Marcion's view, it is really hard to know whether He might not be (after all) the Creator's Christ; because according to him He is not yet come.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:21
verses.text: But whichsoever of the two it is, I want to know why he comes "in all power, and with lying signs and wonders?" "Because," he says, "they received not the love of the truth, that they might be saved; for which cause God shall send them an instinct of delusion (to believe a lie), that they all might be judged who believed not the truth, but had pleasure in unrighteousness".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:22
verses.text: If therefore he be Antichrist, (as we hold), and comes according to the Creator's purpose, it must be God the Creator who sends him to fasten in their error those who did not believe the truth, that they might be saved; His likewise must be the truth and the salvation, who avenges (the contempt of) them by sending error as their substitute—that is, the Creator, to whom that very wrath is a fitting attribute, which deceives with a lie those who are not captivated with truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:23
verses.text: If, however, he is not Antichrist, as we suppose (him to be) then He is the Christ of the Creator, as Marcion will have it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:24
verses.text: In this case how happens it that he can suborn the Creator's Christ to avenge his truth? But should he after all agree with us, that Antichrist is here meant, I must then likewise ask how it is that he finds Satan, an angel of the Creator, necessary to his purpose? Why, too, should Antichrist be slain by Him, whilst commissioned by the Creator to execute the function of inspiring men with their love of untruth?  In short, it is incontestable that the emissary, and the truth, and the salvation belong to Him to whom also appertain the wrath, and the jealousy, and "the sending of the strong delusion," on those who despise and mock, as well as upon those who are ignorant of Him; and therefore even Marcion will now have to come down a step, and concede to us that his god is "a jealous god".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:25
verses.text: (This being then an unquestionable position, I ask) which God has the greater right to be angry? He, as I suppose, who from the beginning of all things has given to man, as primary witnesses for the knowledge of Himself, nature in her (manifold) works, kindly providences, plagues, and indications (of His divinity), but who in spite of all this evidence has not been acknowledged; or he who has been brought out to view once for all in one only copy of the gospel—and even that without any sure authority—which actually makes no secret of proclaiming another god? Now He who has the right of inflicting the vengeance, has also sole claim to that which occasions the vengeance, I mean the Gospel; (in other words,) both the truth and (its accompanying) salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 16:26
verses.text: The charge, that "if any would not work, neither should he eat," is in strict accordance with the precept of Him who ordered that "the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn should not be muzzled".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:1
verses.text: The Epistle to the Laodiceans.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:2
verses.text: The Proper Designation is to the Ephesians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:3
verses.text: Recapitulation of All Things in Christ from the Beginning of the Creation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:4
verses.text: No Room for Marcion's Christ Here.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:5
verses.text: Numerous Parallels Between This Epistle and Passages in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:6
verses.text: The Prince of the Power of the Air, and the God of This World—Who?  Creation and Regeneration the Work of One God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:7
verses.text: How Christ Has Made the Law Obsolete.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:8
verses.text: A Vain Erasure of Marcion's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:9
verses.text: The Apostles as Well as the Prophets from the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:10
verses.text: We have it on the true tradition of the Church, that this epistle was sent to the Ephesians, not to the Laodiceans.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:11
verses.text: Marcion, however, was very desirous of giving it the new title (of Laodicean), as if he were extremely accurate in investigating such a point.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:12
verses.text: But of what consequence are the titles, since in writing to a certain church the apostle did in fact write to all? It is certain that, whoever they were to whom he wrote, he declared Him to be God in Christ with whom all things agree which are predicted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:13
verses.text: Now, to what god will most suitably belong all those things which relate to "that good pleasure, which God hath purposed in the mystery of His will, that in the dispensation of the fulness of times He might recapitulate" (if I may so say, according to the exact meaning of the Greek word) "all things in Christ, both which are in heaven and which are on earth," but to Him whose are all things from their beginning, yea the beginning itself too; from whom issue the times and the dispensation of the fulness of times, according to which all things up to the very first are gathered up in Christ? What beginning, however, has the other god; that is to say, how can anything proceed from him, who has no work to show? And if there be no beginning, how can there be times? If no times, what fulness of times can there be?  And if no fulness, what dispensation? Indeed, what has he ever done on earth, that any long dispensation of times to be fulfilled can be put to his account, for the accomplishment of all things in Christ, even of things in heaven? Nor can we possibly suppose that any things whatever have been at any time done in heaven by any other God than Him by whom, as all men allow, all things have been done on earth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:14
verses.text: Now, if it is impossible for all these things from the beginning to be reckoned to any other God than the Creator, who will believe that an alien god has recapitulated them in an alien Christ, instead of their own proper Author in His own Christ?  If, again, they belong to the Creator, they must needs be separate from the other god; and if separate, then opposed to him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:15
verses.text: But then how can opposites be gathered together into him by whom they are in short destroyed? Again, what Christ do the following words announce, when the apostle says: "That we should be to the praise of His glory, who first trusted in Christ?" Now who could have first trusted—i-e: previously trusted—in God, before His advent, except the Jews to whom Christ was previously announced, from the beginning? He who was thus foretold, was also foretrusted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:16
verses.text: Hence the apostle refers the statement to himself, that is, to the Jews, in order that he may draw a distinction with respect to the Gentiles, (when he goes on to say:) "In whom ye also trusted, after that ye heard the word of truth, the gospel (of your salvation); in whom ye believed, and were sealed with His Holy Spirit of promise".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:17
verses.text: Of what promise? That which was made through Joel: "In the last days will I pour out of my Spirit upon all flesh," that is, on all nations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:18
verses.text: Therefore the Spirit and the Gospel will be found in the Christ, who was foretrusted, because foretold.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:19
verses.text: Again, "the Father of glory" is He whose Christ, when ascending to heaven, is celebrated as "the King of Glory" in the Psalm: "Who is this King of Glory? the Lord of Hosts, He is the King of Glory".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:20
verses.text: From Him also is besought "the spirit of wisdom," at whose disposal is enumerated that sevenfold distribution of the spirit of grace by Isaiah.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:21
verses.text: He likewise will grant "the enlightenment of the eyes of the understanding," who has also enriched our natural eyes with light; to whom, moreover, the blindness of the people is offensive:  "And who is blind, but my servants?…yea, the servants of God have become blind".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:22
verses.text: In His gift, too, are "the riches (of the glory) of His inheritance in the saints," who promised such an inheritance in the call of the Gentiles: "Ask of me, and I will give Thee the heathen for Thine inheritance".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:23
verses.text: It was He who "wrought in Christ His mighty power, by raising Him from the dead, and setting Him at His own right hand, and putting all things under His feet"—even the same who said: "Sit Thou on my right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:24
verses.text: For in another passage the Spirit says to the Father concerning the Son: "Thou hast put all things under His feet".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:25
verses.text: Now, if from all these facts which are found in the Creator there is yet to be deduced another god and another Christ, let us go in quest of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:26
verses.text: I suppose, forsooth, we find Him, when he speaks of such as "were dead in trespasses and sins, wherein they had walked according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, who worketh in the children of disobedience".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:27
verses.text: But Marcion must not here interpret the world as meaning the God of the world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:28
verses.text: For a creature bears no resemblance to the Creator; the thing made, none to its Maker; the world, none to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:29
verses.text: He, moreover, who is the Prince of the power of the ages must not be thought to be called the prince of the power of the air; for He who is chief over the higher powers derives no title from the lower powers, although these, too, may be ascribed to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:30
verses.text: Nor, again, can He possibly seem to be the instigator of that unbelief which He Himself had rather to endure at the hand of the Jews and the Gentiles alike.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:31
verses.text: We may therefore simply conclude that these designations are unsuited to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:32
verses.text: There is another being to whom they are more applicable—and the apostle knew very well who that was.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:33
verses.text: Who then is he? Undoubtedly he who has raised up "children of disobedience" against the Creator Himself ever since he took possession of that "air" of His; even as the prophet makes him say: "I will set my throne above the stars;…I will go up above the clouds; I will be like the Most High".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:34
verses.text: This must mean the devil, whom in another passage (since such will they there have the apostle's meaning to be) we shall recognize in the appellation the god of this world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:35
verses.text: For he has filled the whole world with the lying pretence of his own divinity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:36
verses.text: To be sure, if he had not existed, we might then possibly have applied these descriptions to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:37
verses.text: But the apostle, too, had lived in Judaism; and when he parenthetically observed of the sins (of that period of his life), "in which also we all had our conversation in times past," he must not be understood to indicate that the Creator was the lord of sinful men, and the prince of this air; but as meaning that in his Judaism he had been one of the children of disobedience, having the devil as his instigator—when he persecuted the church and the Christ of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:38
verses.text: Therefore he says: "We also were the children of wrath," but "by nature".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:39
verses.text: Let the heretic, however, not contend that, because the Creator called the Jews children, therefore the Creator is the lord of wrath.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:40
verses.text: For when (the apostle) says, "We were by nature the children of wrath," inasmuch as the Jews were not the Creator's children by nature, but by the election of their fathers, he (must have) referred their being children of wrath to nature, and not to the Creator, adding this at last, "even as others," who, of course, were not children of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:41
verses.text: It is manifest that sins, and lusts of the flesh, and unbelief, and anger, are ascribed to the common nature of all mankind, the devil however leading that nature astray, which he has already infected with the implanted germ of sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:42
verses.text: "We," says he, "are His workmanship, created in Christ".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:43
verses.text: It is one thing to make (as a workman), another thing to create.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:44
verses.text: But he assigns both to One.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:45
verses.text: Man is the workmanship of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:46
verses.text: He therefore who made man (at first), created him also in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:47
verses.text: As touching the substance of nature, He "made" him; as touching the work of grace, He "created" him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:48
verses.text: Look also at what follows in connection with these words:  "Wherefore remember, that ye being in time past Gentiles in the flesh, who are called uncircumcision by that which has the name of circumcision in the flesh made by the hand—that at that time ye were without Christ, being aliens from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants of promise, having no hope, and without God in the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:49
verses.text: Now, without what God and without what Christ were these Gentiles? Surely, without Him to whom the commonwealth of Israel belonged, and the covenants and the promise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:50
verses.text: "But now in Christ," says he, "ye who were sometimes far off are made nigh by His blood".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:51
verses.text: From whom were they far off before? From the (privileges) whereof he speaks above, even from the Christ of the Creator, from the commonwealth of Israel, from the covenants, from the hope of the promise, from God Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:52
verses.text: Since this is the case, the Gentiles are consequently now in Christ made nigh to these (blessings), from which they were once far off.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:53
verses.text: But if we are in Christ brought so very nigh to the commonwealth of Israel, which comprises the religion of the divine Creator, and to the covenants and to the promise, yea to their very God Himself, it is quite ridiculous (to suppose that) the Christ of the other god has brought us to this proximity to the Creator from afar.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:54
verses.text: The apostle had in mind that it had been predicted concerning the call of the Gentiles from their distant alienation in words like these: "They who were far off from me have come to my righteousness".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:55
verses.text: For the Creator's righteousness no less than His peace was announced in Christ, as we have often shown already.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:56
verses.text: Therefore he says: "He is our peace, who hath made both one"—that is, the Jewish nation and the Gentile world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:57
verses.text: What is near, and what was far off now that "the middle wall has been broken down" of their "enmity," (are made one) "in His flesh".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:58
verses.text: But Marcion erased the pronoun His, that he might make the enmity refer to flesh, as if (the apostle spoke) of a carnal enmity, instead of the enmity which was a rival to Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:59
verses.text: And thus you have (as I have said elsewhere) exhibited the stupidity of Pontus, rather than the adroitness of a Marrucinian, for you here deny him flesh to whom in the verse above you allowed blood! Since, however, He has made the law obsolete by His own precepts, even by Himself fulfilling the law (for superfluous is, "Thou shalt not commit adultery," when He says, "Thou shalt not look on a woman to lust after her;" superfluous also is, "Thou shalt do no murder," when He says, "Thou shalt not speak evil of thy neighbour,") it is impossible to make an adversary of the law out of one who so completely promotes it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:60
verses.text: "For to create in Himself of twain," for He who had made is also the same who creates (just as we have found it stated above: "For we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus"), "one new man, making peace" (really new, and really man—no phantom—but new, and newly born of a virgin by the Spirit of God), "that He might reconcile both unto God" (even the God whom both races had offended—both Jew and Gentile), "in one body," says he, "having in it slain the enmity by the cross".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:61
verses.text: Thus we find from this passage also, that there was in Christ a fleshly body, such as was able to endure the cross.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:62
verses.text: "When, therefore, He came and preached peace to them that were near and to them which were afar off," we both obtained "access to the Father," being "now no more strangers and foreigners, but fellow-citizens with the saints, and of the household of God" (even of Him from whom, as we have shown above, we were aliens, and placed far off), "built upon the foundation of the apostles"—(the apostle added), "and the prophets;" these words, however, the heretic erased, forgetting that the Lord had set in His Church not only apostles, but prophets also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:63
verses.text: He feared, no doubt, that our building was to stand in Christ upon the foundation of the ancient prophets, since the apostle himself never fails to build us up everywhere with (the words of) the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 17:64
verses.text: For whence did he learn to call Christ "the chief corner-stone," but from the figure given him in the Psalm:  "The stone which the builders rejected is become the head (stone) of the corner?".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:1
verses.text: Another Foolish Erasure of Marcion's Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:2
verses.text: Certain Figurative Expressions of the Apostle, Suggested by the Language of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:3
verses.text: Collation of Many Passages of This Epistle, with Precepts and Statements in the Pentateuch, the Psalms, and the Prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:4
verses.text: All Alike Teach Us the Will and Purpose of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:5
verses.text: As our heretic is so fond of his pruning-knife, I do not wonder when syllables are expunged by his hand, seeing that entire pages are usually the matter on which he practises his effacing process.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:6
verses.text: The apostle declares that to himself, "less than the least of all saints, was the grace given" of enlightening all men as to "what was the fellowship of the mystery, which during the ages had been hid in God, who created all things".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:7
verses.text: The heretic erased the preposition in, and made the clause run thus: ("what is the fellowship of the mystery) which hath for ages been hidden from the God who created all things".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:8
verses.text: The falsification, however, is flagrantly absurd.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:9
verses.text: For the apostle goes on to infer (from his own statement): "in order that unto the principalities and powers in heavenly places might become known through the church the manifold wisdom of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:10
verses.text: Whose principalities and powers does he mean?  If the Creator's, how does it come to pass that such a God as He could have meant His wisdom to be displayed to the principalities and powers, but not to Himself? For surely no principalities could possibly have understood anything without their sovereign Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:11
verses.text: Or if (the apostle) did not mention God in this passage, on the ground that He (as their chief) is Himself reckoned among these (principalities), then he would have plainly said that the mystery had been hidden from the principalities and powers of Him who had created all things, including Him amongst them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:12
verses.text: But if he states that it was hidden from them, he must needs be understood as having meant that it was manifest to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:13
verses.text: From God, therefore, the mystery was not hidden; but it was hidden in God, the Creator of all things, from His principalities and powers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:14
verses.text: For "who hath known the mind of the Lord, or who hath been His counsellor?" Caught in this trap, the heretic probably changed the passage, with the view of saying that his god wished to make known to his principalities and powers the fellowship of his own mystery, of which God, who created all things, had been ignorant.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:15
verses.text: But what was the use of his obtruding this ignorance of the Creator, who was a stranger to the superior god, and far enough removed from him, when even his own servants had known nothing about him? To the Creator, however, the future was well known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:16
verses.text: Then why was not that also known to Him, which had to be revealed beneath His heaven, and on His earth? From this, therefore, there arises a confirmation of what we have already laid down.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:17
verses.text: For since the Creator was sure to know, some time or other, that hidden mystery of the superior god, even on the supposition that the true reading was (as Marcion has it)—"hidden from the God who created all things"—he ought then to have expressed the conclusion thus: "in order that the manifold wisdom of God might be made known to Him, and then to the principalities and powers of God, whosoever He might be, with whom the Creator was destined to share their knowledge".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:18
verses.text: So palpable is the erasure in this passage, when thus read, consistently with its own true bearing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:19
verses.text: I, on my part, now wish to engage with you in a discussion on the allegorical expressions of the apostle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:20
verses.text: What figures of speech could the novel god have found in the prophets (fit for himself)?  "He led captivity captive," says the apostle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:21
verses.text: With what arms? In what conflicts? From the devastation of what country? From the overthrow of what city? What women, what children, what princes did the Conqueror throw into chains? For when by David Christ is sung as "girded with His sword upon His thigh," or by Isaiah as "taking away the spoils of Samaria and the power of Damascus," you make Him out to be really and truly a warrior confest to the eye.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:22
verses.text: Learn then now, that His is a spiritual armour and warfare, since you have already discovered that the captivity is spiritual, in order that you may further learn that this also belongs to Him, even because the apostle derived the mention of the captivity from the same prophets as suggested to him his precepts likewise: "Putting away lying," (says he,) "speak every man truth with his neighbour;" and again, using the very words in which the Psalm expresses his meaning, (he says,) "Be ye angry, and sin not;" "Let not the sun go down upon your wrath".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:23
verses.text: "Have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness;" for (in the Psalm it is written,) "With the holy man thou shalt be holy, and with the perverse thou shalt be perverse;" and, "Thou shalt put away evil from among you".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:24
verses.text: Again, "Go ye out from the midst of them; touch not the unclean thing; separate yourselves, ye that bear the vessels of the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:25
verses.text: (The apostle says further:) "Be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess,"—a precept which is suggested by the passage (of the prophet), where the seducers of the consecrated (Nazarites) to drunkenness are rebuked: "Ye gave wine to my holy ones to drink".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:26
verses.text: This prohibition from drink was given also to the high priest Aaron and his sons, "when they went into the holy place".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:27
verses.text: The command, to "sing to the Lord with psalms and hymns," comes suitably from him who knew that those who "drank wine with drums and psalteries" were blamed by God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:28
verses.text: Now, when I find to what God belong these precepts, whether in their germ or their development, I have no difficulty in knowing to whom the apostle also belongs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:29
verses.text: But he declares that "wives ought to be in subjection to their husbands:" what reason does he give for this? "Because," says he, "the husband is the head of the wife".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:30
verses.text: Pray tell me, Marcion, does your god build up the authority of his law on the work of the Creator? This, however, is a comparative trifle; for he actually derives from the same source the condition of his Christ and his Church; for he says: "even as Christ is the head of the Church;" and again, in like manner: "He who loveth his wife, loveth his own flesh, even as Christ loved the Church".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:31
verses.text: You see how your Christ and your Church are put in comparison with the work of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:32
verses.text: How much honour is given to the flesh in the name of the church! "No man," says the apostle, "ever yet hated his own flesh" (except, of course, Marcion alone), "but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as the Lord doth the Church".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:33
verses.text: But you are the only man that hates his flesh, for you rob it of its resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:34
verses.text: It will be only right that you should hate the Church also, because it is loved by Christ on the same principle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:35
verses.text: Yea, Christ loved the flesh even as the Church.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:36
verses.text: For no man will love the picture of his wife without taking care of it, and honouring it and crowning it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:37
verses.text: The likeness partakes with the reality in the privileged honour.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:38
verses.text: I shall now endeavour, from my point of view, to prove that the same God is (the God) of the man and of Christ, of the woman and of the Church, of the flesh and the spirit, by the apostle's help who applies the Creator's injunction, and adds even a comment on it: "For this cause shall a man leave his father and his mother, (and shall be joined unto his wife), and they two shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:39
verses.text: This is a great mystery".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:40
verses.text: In passing, (I would say that) it is enough for me that the works of the Creator are great mysteries in the estimation of the apostle, although they are so vilely esteemed by the heretics.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:41
verses.text: "But I am speaking," says he, "of Christ and the Church".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:42
verses.text: This he says in explanation of the mystery, not for its disruption.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:43
verses.text: He shows us that the mystery was prefigured by Him who is also the author of the mystery.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:44
verses.text: Now what is Marcion's opinion? The Creator could not possibly have furnished figures to an unknown god, or, if a known one, an adversary to Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:45
verses.text: The superior god, in fact, ought to have borrowed nothing from the inferior; he was bound rather to annihilate Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:46
verses.text: "Children should obey their parents".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:47
verses.text: Now, although Marcion has erased (the next clause), "which is the first commandment with promise," still the law says plainly, "Honour thy father and thy mother".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:48
verses.text: Again, (the apostle writes:) "Parents, bring up your children in the fear and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:49
verses.text: For you have heard how it was said to them of old time: "Ye shall relate these things to your children; and your children in like manner to their children".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:50
verses.text: Of what use are two gods to me, when the discipline is but one? If there must be two, I mean to follow Him who was the first to teach the lesson.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:51
verses.text: But as our struggle lies against "the rulers of this world," what a host of Creator Gods there must be! For why should I not insist upon this point here, that he ought to have mentioned but one "ruler of this world," if he meant only the Creator to be the being to whom belonged all the powers which he previously mentioned? Again, when in the preceding verse he bids us "put on the whole armour of God, that we may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil," does he not show that all the things which he mentions after the devil's name really belong to the devil—"the principalities and the powers, and the rulers of the darkness of this world," which we also ascribe to the devil's authority?  Else, if "the devil" means the Creator, who will be the devil in the Creator's dispensation? As there are two gods, must there also be two devils, and a plurality of powers and rulers of this world? But how is the Creator both a devil and a god at the same time, when the devil is not at once both god and devil? For either they are both of them gods, if both of them are devils; or else He who is God is not also devil, as neither is he god who is the devil.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:52
verses.text: I want to know indeed by what perversion the word devil is at all applicable to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:53
verses.text: Perhaps he perverted some purpose of the superior god—conduct such as He experienced Himself from the archangel, who lied indeed for the purpose.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:54
verses.text: For He did not forbid (our first parents) a taste of the miserable tree, from any apprehension that they would become gods; His prohibition was meant to prevent their dying after the transgression.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:55
verses.text: But "the spiritual wickedness" did not signify the Creator, because of the apostle's additional description, "in heavenly places;" for the apostle was quite aware that "spiritual wickedness" had been at work in heavenly places, when angels were entrapped into sin by the daughters of men.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 18:56
verses.text: But how happened it that (the apostle) resorted to ambiguous descriptions, and I know not what obscure enigmas, for the purpose of disparaging the Creator, when he displayed to the Church such constancy and plainness of speech in "making known the mystery of the gospel for which he was an ambassador in bonds," owing to his liberty in preaching—and actually requested (the Ephesians) to pray to God that this "open-mouthed utterance" might be continued to him?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:1
verses.text: The Epistle to the Colossians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:2
verses.text: Time the Criterion of Truth and Heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:3
verses.text: Application of the Canon.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:4
verses.text: The Image of the Invisible God Explained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:5
verses.text: Pre-Existence of Our Christ in the Creator's Ancient Dispensations.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:6
verses.text: What is Included in the Fulness of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:7
verses.text: The Epicurean Character of Marcion's God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:8
verses.text: The Catholic Truth in Opposition Thereto.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:9
verses.text: The Law is to Christ What the Shadow is to the Substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:10
verses.text: I am accustomed in my prescription against all heresies, to fix my compendious criterion (of truth) in the testimony of time; claiming priority therein as our rule, and alleging lateness to be the characteristic of every heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:11
verses.text: This shall now be proved even by the apostle, when he says: "For the hope which is laid up for you in heaven, whereof ye heard before in the word of the truth of the gospel; which is come unto you, as it is unto all the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:12
verses.text: For if, even at that time, the tradition of the gospel had spread everywhere, how much more now! Now, if it is our gospel which has spread everywhere, rather than any heretical gospel, much less Marcion's, which only dates from the reign of Antoninus, then ours will be the gospel of the apostles.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:13
verses.text: But should Marcion's gospel succeed in filling the whole world, it would not even in that case be entitled to the character of apostolic.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:14
verses.text: For this quality, it will be evident, can only belong to that gospel which was the first to fill the world; in other words, to the gospel of that God who of old declared this of its promulgation: "Their sound is gone out through all the earth, and their words to the end of the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:15
verses.text: He calls Christ "the image of the invisible God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:16
verses.text: We in like manner say that the Father of Christ is invisible, for we know that it was the Son who was seen in ancient times (whenever any appearance was vouchsafed to men in the name of God) as the image of (the Father) Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:17
verses.text: He must not be regarded, however, as making any difference between a visible and an invisible God; because long before he wrote this we find a description of our God to this effect: "No man can see the Lord, and live".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:18
verses.text: If Christ is not "the first-begotten before every creature," as that "Word of God by whom all things were made, and without whom nothing was made;" if "all things were" not "in Him created, whether in heaven or on earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones or dominions, or principalities, or powers;" if "all things were" not "created by Him and for Him" (for these truths Marcion ought not to allow concerning Him), then the apostle could not have so positively laid it down, that "He is before all".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:19
verses.text: For how is He before all, if He is not before all things? How, again, is He before all things, if He is not "the first-born of every creature"—if He is not the Word of the Creator? Now how will he be proved to have been before all things, who appeared after all things?  Who can tell whether he had a prior existence, when he has found no proof that he had any existence at all?  In what way also could it have "pleased (the Father) that in Him should all fulness dwell?" For, to begin with, what fulness is that which is not comprised of the constituents which Marcion has removed from it,—even those that were "created in Christ, whether in heaven or on earth," whether angels or men? which is not made of the things that are visible and invisible? which consists not of thrones and dominions and principalities and powers? If, on the other hand, our false apostles and Judaizing gospellers have introduced all these things out of their own stores, and Marcion has applied them to constitute the fulness of his own god, (this hypothesis, absurd though it be, alone would justify him;) for how, on any other supposition, could the rival and the destroyer of the Creator have been willing that His fulness should dwell in his Christ? To whom, again, does He "reconcile all things by Himself, making peace by the blood of His cross," but to Him whom those very things had altogether offended, against whom they had rebelled by transgression, (but) to whom they had at last returned? Conciliated they might have been to a strange god; but reconciled they could not possibly have been to any other than their own God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:20
verses.text: Accordingly, ourselves "who were sometime alienated and enemies in our mind by wicked works" does He reconcile to the Creator, against whom we had committed offence—worshipping the creature to the prejudice of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:21
verses.text: As, however, he says elsewhere, that the Church is the body of Christ, so here also (the apostle) declares that he "fills up that which is behind of the afflictions of Christ in his flesh for His body's sake, which is the Church".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:22
verses.text: But you must not on this account suppose that on every mention of His body the term is only a metaphor, instead of meaning real flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:23
verses.text: For he says above that we are "reconciled in His body through death;" meaning, of course, that He died in that body wherein death was possible through the flesh: (therefore he adds,) not through the Church (per ecclesiam), but expressly for the sake of the Church (proper ecclesiam), exchanging body for body—one of flesh for a spiritual one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:24
verses.text: When, again, he warns them to "beware of subtle words and philosophy," as being "a vain deceit," such as is "after the rudiments of the world" (not understanding thereby the mundane fabric of sky and earth, but worldly learning, and "the tradition of men," subtle in their speech and their philosophy), it would be tedious, and the proper subject of a separate work, to show how in this sentence (of the apostle's) all heresies are condemned, on the ground of their consisting of the resources of subtle speech and the rules of philosophy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:25
verses.text: But (once for all) let Marcion know that the principle term of his creed comes from the school of Epicurus, implying that the Lord is stupid and indifferent; wherefore he refuses to say that He is an object to be feared.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:26
verses.text: Moreover, from the porch of the Stoics he brings out matter, and places it on a par with the Divine Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:27
verses.text: He also denies the resurrection of the flesh,—a truth which none of the schools of philosophy agreed together to hold.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:28
verses.text: But how remote is our (Catholic) verity from the artifices of this heretic, when it dreads to arouse the anger of God, and firmly believes that He produced all things out of nothing, and promises to us a restoration from the grave of the same flesh (that died) and holds without a blush that Christ was born of the virgin's womb! At this, philosophers, and heretics, and the very heathen, laugh and jeer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:29
verses.text: For "God hath chosen the foolish things of the world to confound the wise"—that God, no doubt, who in reference to this very dispensation of His threatened long before that He would "destroy the wisdom of the wise".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:30
verses.text: Thanks to this simplicity of truth, so opposed to the subtlety and vain deceit of philosophy, we cannot possibly have any relish for such perverse opinions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:31
verses.text: Then, if God "quickens us together with Christ, forgiving us our trespasses," we cannot suppose that sins are forgiven by Him against whom, as having been all along unknown, they could not have been committed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:32
verses.text: Now tell me, Marcion, what is your opinion of the apostle's language, when he says, "Let no man judge you in meat, or in drink, or in respect of a holy day, or of the new moon, or of the sabbath, which is a shadow of things to come, but the body is of Christ?" We do not now treat of the law, further than (to remark) that the apostle here teaches clearly how it has been abolished, even by passing from shadow to substance—that is, from figurative types to the reality, which is Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:33
verses.text: The shadow, therefore, is His to whom belongs the body also; in other words, the law is His, and so is Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:34
verses.text: If you separate the law and Christ, assigning one to one god and the other to another, it is the same as if you were to attempt to separate the shadow from the body of which it is the shadow.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:35
verses.text: Manifestly Christ has relation to the law, if the body has to its shadow.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:36
verses.text: But when he blames those who alleged visions of angels as their authority for saying that men must abstain from meats—"you must not touch, you must not taste"—in a voluntary humility, (at the same time) "vainly puffed up in the fleshly mind, and not holding the Head," (the apostle) does not in these terms attack the law or Moses, as if it was at the suggestion of superstitious angels that he had enacted his prohibition of sundry aliments.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:37
verses.text: For Moses had evidently received the law from God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:38
verses.text: When, therefore, he speaks of their "following the commandments and doctrines of men," he refers to the conduct of those persons who "held not the Head," even Him in whom all things are gathered together; for they are all recalled to Christ, and concentrated in Him as their initiating principle—even the meats and drinks which were indifferent in their nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 19:39
verses.text: All the rest of his precepts, as we have shown sufficiently, when treating of them as they occurred in another epistle, emanated from the Creator, who, while predicting that "old things were to pass away," and that He would "make all things new," commanded men "to break up fresh ground for themselves," and thereby taught them even then to put off the old man and put on the new.

verses.text: St.

verses.text: Paul's Phrases—Form of a Servant, Likeness, and Fashion of a Man—No Sanction of Docetism.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:5
verses.text: No Antithesis (Such as Marcion Alleged) in the God of Judaism and the God of the Gospel Deducible from Certain Contrasts Mentioned in This Epistle.
