verses.text: The Resurrection of the Body, and the Change Thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:8
verses.text: When (the apostle) mentions the several motives of those who were preaching the gospel, how that some, "waxing confident by his bonds, were more fearless in speaking the word," while others "preached Christ even out of envy and strife, and again others out of good-will," many also "out of love," and certain "out of contention," and some "in rivalry to himself," he had a favourable opportunity, no doubt, of taxing what they preached with a diversity of doctrine, as if it were no less than this which caused so great a variance in their tempers.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:9
verses.text: But while he exposes these tempers as the sole cause of the diversity, he avoids inculpating the regular mysteries of the faith, and affirms that there is, notwithstanding, but one Christ and His one God, whatever motives men had in preaching Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:10
verses.text: Therefore, says he, it matters not to me "whether it be in pretence or in truth that Christ is preached," because one Christ alone was announced, whether in their "pretentious" or their "truthful" faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:11
verses.text: For it was to the faithfulness of their preaching that he applied the word truth, not to the rightness of the rule itself, because there was indeed but one rule; whereas the conduct of the preachers varied: in some of them it was true, i-e: single-minded, while in others it was sophisticated with over-much learning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:12
verses.text: This being the case, it is manifest that that Christ was the subject of their preaching who was always the theme of the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:13
verses.text: Now, if it were a completely different Christ that was being introduced by the apostle, the novelty of the thing would have produced a diversity (in belief.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:15
verses.text: For there would not have been wanting, in spite of the novel teaching, men to interpret the preached gospel of the Creator's Christ, since the majority of persons everywhere now-a-days are of our way of thinking, rather than on the heretical side.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:16
verses.text: So that the apostle would not in such a passage as the present one have refrained from remarking and censuring the diversity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:17
verses.text: Since, however, there is no blame of a diversity, there is no proof of a novelty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:18
verses.text: Of course the Marcionites suppose that they have the apostle on their side in the following passage in the matter of Christ's substance—that in Him there was nothing but a phantom of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:19
verses.text: For he says of Christ, that, "being in the form of God, He thought it not robbery to be equal with God; but emptied Himself, and took upon Him the form of a servant," not the reality, "and was made in the likeness of man," not a man, "and was found in fashion as a man," not in his substance, that is to say, his flesh; just as if to a substance there did not accrue both form and likeness and fashion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:20
verses.text: It is well for us that in another passage (the apostle) calls Christ "the image of the invisible God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:21
verses.text: For will it not follow with equal force from that passage, that Christ is not truly God, because the apostle places Him in the image of God, if, (as Marcion contends,) He is not truly man because of His having taken on Him the form or image of a man? For in both cases the true substance will have to be excluded, if image (or "fashion") and likeness and form shall be claimed for a phantom.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:22
verses.text: But since he is truly God, as the Son of the Father, in His fashion and image, He has been already by the force of this conclusion determined to be truly man, as the Son of man, "found in the fashion" and image "of a man".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:23
verses.text: For when he propounded Him as thus "found" in the manner of a man, he in fact affirmed Him to be most certainly human.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:24
verses.text: For what is found, manifestly possesses existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:25
verses.text: Therefore, as He was found to be God by His mighty power, so was He found to be man by reason of His flesh, because the apostle could not have pronounced Him to have "become obedient unto death," if He had not been constituted of a mortal substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:26
verses.text: Still more plainly does this appear from the apostle's additional words, "even the death of the cross".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:27
verses.text: For he could hardly mean this to be a climax to the human suffering, to extol the virtue of His obedience, if he had known it all to be the imaginary process of a phantom, which rather eluded the cross than experienced it, and which displayed no virtue in the suffering, but only illusion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:28
verses.text: But "those things which he had once accounted gain," and which he enumerates in the preceding verse—"trust in the flesh," the sign of "circumcision," his origin as "an Hebrew of the Hebrews," his descent from "the tribe of Benjamin," his dignity in the honours of the Pharisee—he now reckons to be only "loss" to himself; (in other words,) it was not the God of the Jews, but their stupid obduracy, which he repudiates.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:29
verses.text: These are also the things "which he counts but dung for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ" (but by no means for the rejection of God the Creator); "whilst he has not his own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through Him," i-e: Christ, "the righteousness which is of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:30
verses.text: Then, say you, according to this distinction the law did not proceed from the God of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:31
verses.text: Subtle enough! But here is something still more subtle for you.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:32
verses.text: For when (the apostle) says, "Not (the righteousness) which is of the law, but that which is through Him," he would not have used the phrase through Him of any other than Him to whom the law belonged.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:33
verses.text: "Our conversation," says he, "is in heaven".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:34
verses.text: I here recognise the Creator's ancient promise to Abraham: "I will multiply thy seed as the stars of heaven".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:35
verses.text: Therefore "one star differeth from another star in glory".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:36
verses.text: If, again, Christ in His advent from heaven "shall change the body of our humiliation, that it may be fashioned like unto His glorious body," it follows that this body of ours shall rise again, which is now in a state of humiliation in its sufferings and according to the law of mortality drops into the ground.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:37
verses.text: But how shall it be changed, if it shall have no real existence? If, however, this is only said of those who shall be found in the flesh at the advent of God, and who shall have to be changed," what shall they do who will rise first?  They will have no substance from which to undergo a change.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:38
verses.text: But he says (elsewhere), "We shall be caught up together with them in the clouds, to meet the Lord (in the air)".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 20:39
verses.text: Then, if we are to be caught up alone with them, surely we shall likewise be changed together with them.

verses.text: To this epistle alone did its brevity avail to protect it against the falsifying hands of Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 21:7
verses.text: I wonder, however, when he received (into his Apostolicon) this letter which was written but to one man, that he rejected the two epistles to Timothy and the one to Titus, which all treat of ecclesiastical discipline.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 21:8
verses.text: His aim, was, I suppose, to carry out his interpolating process even to the number of (St.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 21:10
verses.text: And now, reader, I beg you to remember that we have here adduced proofs out of the apostle, in support of the subjects which we previously had to handle, and that we have now brought to a close the topics which we deferred to this (portion of our) work.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 21:11
verses.text: (This favour I request of you,) that you may not think that any repetition here has been superfluous, for we have only fulfilled our former engagement to you; nor look with suspicion on any postponement there, where we merely set forth the essential points (of the argument).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 21:12
verses.text: If you carefully examine the entire work, you will acquit us of either having been redundant here, or diffident there, in your own honest judgment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:18
verses.text: -  He who has followed Tertullian through the mazes in which Marcion, in spite of shifts and turnings innumerable, has been hunted down, and defeated, must recognize the great work performed by this author in behalf of Christian Orthodoxy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:19
verses.text: It seems to have been the plan of Christ's watchful care over His Church, that, in the earliest stages of its existence the enemy should be allowed to display his utmost malice and to bring out all his forces against Truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:20
verses.text: Thus, before the meeting of Church-councils the language of faith had grown up, and clear views and precise statements of doctrine had been committed to the idioms of human thought.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:21
verses.text: But, the labours of Tertullian are not confined to these diverse purposes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:22
verses.text: With all the faults of his acute and forensic mind, how powerfully he illuminates the Scriptures and glorifies them as containing the whole system of the Faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:23
verses.text: How rich are his quotations, and how penetrating his conceptions of their uses.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:24
verses.text: Besides all this, what an introduction he gives us to the modes of thought which were becoming familiar in the West, and which were convening the Latin tongue to new uses, and making it capable of expressing Augustine's mind and so of creating new domains of Learning among the nations of Europe.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book V 22:25
verses.text: If I have treated tenderly the reputation of this great Master, in my notes upon his Marcion, it is with a twofold purpose.
